Portal inflammation, periportal fibrosis, focal necrosis with progression to parenchymal fibrosis, cholestasis and haemosiderosis have been recorded. [1755] [1756] [1757] [1758] [1759] [1760] In a survey of the literature, Gilchrist et al. 1757 found a reduction of 'cholangioles' in 23% of cases. Patients with severe fibrosis and disruption of the parenchyma [1759] [1760] [1761] [1762] [1763] and even cirrhosis 1750, 1764, 1765 have been described.

The absence of peroxisomes in liver cells, first described by Goldfischer et al., 1766 has been a consistent finding in subsequent ultrastructural studies. 5, 1749, 1759, 1760 In some cases, however, small bodies resembling incompletely developed peroxisomes could be found. 5 A variant of the disease with detectable hepatic peroxisomes has also been reported. 1767 Another ultrastructural feature is the occurrence within macrophages of large, angulate lysosomes filled with fine, double lamellae. 1759 Mitochondria show derangement and twisting of their cristae and have a dense matrix. 5, 1759, 1768 The absence of catalase, a peroxisomal enzyme, was demonstrated at the ultrastructural level in a liver biopsy specimen from a patient with Zellweger syndrome. A diffuse rather than granular pattern of staining using anticalase antibodies on formalin-fixed paraffin-embedded (FFPE) tissue is observed in patients with Zellweger syndrome. 1769 Several other peroxisomal enzymes can also be demonstrated by immunogold labelling. 1770

Less severe variants of classic Zellweger syndrome include neonatal adrenoleucodystrophy and infantile Refsum disease. 1745 The dysmorphic features are less striking than those of classic Zellweger syndrome, and the peroxisomes in the liver are not as markedly diminished. 1771 Because these diseases are generally milder, with some hope for neurological development, controlled clinical trials of therapies to bypass the deficient peroxisomal enzymes have been initiated. 1772 A single case of neonatal liver failure associated with X-linked adrenoleucodystrophy has been described. 1773 In adrenoleucodystrophy, there is variable fibrosis and irregular nodularity of the hepatic parenchyma. 1774, 1775 Cirrhosis was reported in one patient. 1776 PASpositive macrophages and Kupffer cells were identified in another. 1777 Ultrastructurally, hepatic peroxisomes are either absent or greatly reduced in number and size 1771, 1776 and may contain electron-dense cores. 1778 Lamellar cytoplasmic inclusions are found in Kupffer cells and hepatocytes. 1777, 1778 Mitochondria with crystalline inclusions and/or abnormal cristae have also been noted. 1778 (primary hyperoxaluria type 1), ether phospholipid biosynthesis, bile acid synthesis and hydrogen peroxide (H 2 O 2 ) metabolism.
body_text.section: Neonatal adrenoleucodystrophy and infantile Refsum disease

body_text.text: The disorders described in this section include X-linked adrenoleucodystrophy, di-and trihydroxycholestanoic acidaemia, mevalonate kinase deficiency and adult Refsum disease. Some of the other disorders are discussed in the relevant disease sections. 1734 At least 21 genetic disorders have now been found that are linked to peroxisomal dysfunction. 1735 Only the peroxisomal disorders that result in liver disease-Zellweger syndrome, di-and trihydroxycholestanoic acidaemia and mevalonate kinase deficiency-are discussed.
body_text.section: Neonatal adrenoleucodystrophy and infantile Refsum disease

body_text.text: Diseases of the Zellweger spectrum represent a continuum of clinical disorders with Zellweger syndrome having the most severe phenotype and neonatal adrenoleukodystrophy, infantile Refsum disease and Heimler syndrome having progressively milder phenotypes. The Zellweger syndrome spectrum is caused by defects in any of at least 12 peroxin (PEX) genes required for normal organelle assembly. Most common are mutations in PEX1, which encodes a 143-kD ATPases Associated with diverse cellular Activities (AAA) ATPase protein needed for peroxisome biogenesis, followed by PEX26, PEX6, PEX12, PEX10 and PEX2. 1736 The PEX1 mutations identified to date comprise insertions, deletions, nonsense, missense and splice site mutations. Mutations that produce premature truncation codons (PTCs) are distributed throughout the PEX1 gene, whereas the majority of missense mutations segregate with the two essential AAA domains of the PEX1 protein. Severity at the two ends of the Zellweger spectrum correlates broadly with mutation type and impact (i.e. the severe syndrome correlates with PTCs on both alleles, and the milder phenotypes correlate with missense mutations), but exceptions to these general correlations exist. 1737 Chromosomes 12, 8, 7 and 6 contain loci associated with Zellweger disease spectrum. [1738] [1739] [1740] [1741] [1742] [1743] [1744] Zellweger syndrome Patients present at birth with a characteristic facial dysmorphia, severe hypotonia, hepatomegaly, renal cysts, optic atrophy, seizures and severe neurological impairment. 1745 Diagnosis is made through a combination of studies that include plasma quantitation of cervical region. Serum IgD levels (>100 U/mL) remain elevated during the attack, most often associated with raised IgA levels. 1789 The diagnosis is confirmed by MVK gene screening, in particular the V377I mutation, which has been identified exclusively in HIDS patients. 1794, 1795 Hepatomegaly is common, and cholestatic liver disease has been recorded, 1793 but detailed histological changes in these disorders are not available. Mild portal fibrosis with a mainly lymphocytic inflammatory cell infiltrate is mentioned in a case report of a child with MVK deficiency. 1796

Mitochondrial cytopathies comprise a broad array of diseases affecting multiple organ systems. [1797] [1798] [1799] [1800] A mitochondriopathy, defined as a disorder of mitochondrial function or structure, may result in combinations of many diverse symptoms, including hepatic failure, or cholestasis with preserved liver function, cardiomyopathy, pigmentary retinopathy, myoclonic seizures, hypotonia, proximal tubular disorder, endocrinopathies or pancytopenia, pancreatic deficiency or gut dismotility. Disease severity is highly variable, as are the time of presentation and rate of disease progression. Many of these disorders affect the neuromuscular system with no known hepatic involvement. This section focuses on mitochondrial disorders in which liver disease is a prominent clinical feature. Most of these are genetic disorders. Acquired hepatic mitochondrial disorders, for example, associated with toxicity of nucleoside analogue retroviral drugs or with chronic viral hepatitis, are discussed in other chapters. Inherited hepatic mitochondriopathies tend to present clinically in infancy or childhood; late hepatic involvement is less common.

Classification of the mitochondriopathies is also challenging, especially as the number of known mitochondrial cytopathies continues to expand. Diseases can be classified by the genetic defect (autosomal or mitochondrial) or by the affected enzymatic system (oxidative phosphorylation or fatty acid oxidation). A comprehensive classification of mitochondrial disease has been proposed, 1801 as well as one focusing on liver involvement. 1802 Table 3 .6 provides a classification of hepatic mitochondriopathies.

Mitochondria produce ATP within cells and, coincidentally, activated oxygen species; in hepatocytes, mitochondria play an important role in β-oxidation. Mitochondria are unique among cell organelles in having their own complement of DNA, which encodes some of the proteins in the respiratory chain responsible for oxidative phosphorylation, as well as specific RNAs critical to protein synthesis in mitochondria. Inheritance of mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) is along maternal lines. Mitochondria are derived almost exclusively from the ovum, since sperm contain very few mitochondria. Mitochondria have their own DNA polymerase, polymerase γ (POLG, or POLγ), for production of mtDNA. Proofreading and DNA repair capacities are extremely limited in mitochondria. Tissue expression of mtDNA abnormalities is complex, depending on the population of mitochondria in each cell. Gene localization and determination of specific genetic defects are available for some of the mitochondriopathies. Lack of simple one-to-one correspondence of a certain mtDNA mutation to a clinical disease pattern, along with the feature of heteroplasmy, has made genotype-phenotype correlations especially difficult.

Mitochondrial disorders are rare, but their exact incidence is undetermined, mainly because accurate diagnosis previously was difficult. Clinically, the mitochondrial cytopathies with liver disease present principally in two ways. 1803 First, severe liver disease may be evident during the first week of life; mitochondrial disorders constitute An accentuated lobular architecture, with fibrous bands linking portal areas together, has been observed in Refsum disease. 1779 A micronodular cirrhosis was found in a patient who died at age 12 years. 1779 A deficiency of hepatic peroxisomes has been detected ultrastructurally and cytochemically. [1780] [1781] [1782] Phillips et al. 5 believes that while some hepatocytes totally lack peroxisomes, others contain very small, underdeveloped peroxisomes that sometimes have a very dense matrix. Numerous angulate lysosomes have also been noted in Kupffer cells in this disorder.

Patients with this rare disease present with severe cholestasis and obstructive jaundice. Trihydroxycoprostanic acid coenzyme A (THCA-CoA), a bile acid ester, is converted to δ 4 -THCA initiated by a specific THCA-CoA oxidase. Similarly, acid is also processed in the peroxisomes. In di-and trihydroxycholestanoic acidaemia ('alligator bile syndrome'), serum levels of these precursors are high because either transport of the CoA ester into the peroxisome or subsequent processing is deficient. [1783] [1784] [1785] An isolated case of THCA-CoA has been subsequently reallocated to a peroxisomal biogenesis disorder on the basis of mutations in the PEX12 gene, although all peroxisomal functions in cultured skin fibroblasts were normal, leading the author to question the existence of THCA-CoA as an entity. 1786

The gene encoding mevalonate kinase (MVK) was mapped by FISH to chromosome 14q24. 1787 Gene mutations lead to two groups of disorders: (1) mevalonate aciduria, the first recognized defect in the biosynthesis of cholesterol and isoprenoids, resulting from severe deficiency in MVK, 1788 and (2) hyperimmunoglobulinaemia D (hyper-IgD) syndrome/periodic fever, seemingly associated with mild deficiency. 1789 MVK deficiency is included in the monogenic autoinflammatory syndromes, a group of disorders manifesting with inflammatory symptoms of variable degree of severity, duration and frequency due to dysregulation of the innate immune system. 1790, 1791 The clinical spectrum of mevalonate aciduria shows varying degrees of severity despite a uniformly absent MVK activity in all. Severely affected patients have profound developmental delay, dysmorphic facies, cataracts, hepatosplenomegaly, lymphadenopathy and anaemia, as well as diarrhoea and malabsorption, and die in infancy. Less severely affected patients have psychomotor retardation, hypotonia, myopathy and ataxia. All patients will have recurrent crises, with fever, lymphadenopathy, increased size of liver and spleen, arthralgia, oedema and morbilliform rash. 1788, 1792 Haematological anomalies, in particular anaemia, petechiae, cutaneous extramedullary haematopoiesis, hepatosplenomegaly, leukocytosis, recurrent febrile episodes and facial rashes, in patients without significant neurologic abnormalities raise the differential diagnosis of congenital infections, myelodysplastic syndromes or chronic leukaemia. 1793 Mevalonic acid concentrations are grossly elevated in body fluids in all patients because of disordered biosynthesis of cholesterol. Mevalonic acid can be detected clinically by urinary organic acid analysis. Prenatal diagnosis is possible by measurement of mevalonic acid in amniotic fluid. 1788 Hyper-IgD syndrome (HIDS)/periodic fever is characterized by recurrent attacks of spiking fever with early onset before 1 year of age, associated with abdominal pains (72%), vomiting (56%), diarrhoea (82%), polyarthralgia (80%) and nondestructive arthritis (68%); 82% of patients report skin lesions, with vasculitis histologically. Swollen, tender lymph nodes are noted most often in the demanding technically and generally relies on molecular techniques. Meticulous evaluation for a hepatic mitochondriopathy is mandatory for assessing the infant with neonatal liver failure of any type, and whenever liver transplantation (LT) might be a treatment option. 1806 Accumulating evidence indicates that many infants with mitochondrial disorders exhibit abnormalities before birth. 1808 Prenatal diagnosis depends on identification and cloning of mutant genes or direct measurement of mitochondrial metabolism in cultured chorionic villus cells or amniocytes. 1809 If the gene involved in the mitochondriopathy of a previously affected sibling has been identified, the family can benefit from prenatal diagnosis. If a family with a known mitochondrial disorder desires prenatal diagnosis, a centre specializing in these disorders should be contacted to determine the status of prenatal diagnosis of the particular disease.

Therapy for the mitochondrial disorders vary with the disease. Intensive supportive care is required for the neonate with hepatic failure, especially to permit accurate diagnosis and comprehensive evaluation of extrahepatic involvement. Patients with the more delayed form of liver disease may need supportive treatment, including nutritional and metabolic strategies; neurological features may require antiepileptic medication, which must be specifically selected and monitored to avoid exacerbating hepatic disease. In some cases, use of a 'mitochondrial cocktail' has been said to improve a patient's clinical condition, 1810 but benefits may be uncertain unless a specific deficiency can be supplemented. 1811 Treatment for fatty acid oxidation disorders is customized to the actual defect. 1812, 1813 LT is controversial. In general, the outcome has been poor. Nevertheless several authors an important etiology for neonatal liver failure. Such patients die suddenly or appear to be septic. Typical patients have transient hypoglycaemia, severe neurological involvement (hypotonia, myoclonic seizures, developmental delay) and hepatic failure with a rapidly fatal clinical course. [1803] [1804] [1805] In some patients the neonatal liver failure dominates the clinical picture, and extrahepatic involvement is either not present or difficult to discern. Alternatively, the onset of symptoms is delayed such that clinical presentation occurs between 2 and 18 months of age. Liver disease is less severe initially (although hepatic failure occurs progressively), neurological involvement is variable, and some patients survive for an extended period. This second group includes 'Alpers progressive infantile poliodystrophy', now known as Alpers syndrome. A third possible clinical presentation is chronic liver disease with liver enlargement and possibly hepatic steatosis or cirrhosis; if sought, hypoglycaemia or lactic acidosis may be found.

Screening for a mitochondrial disorder includes a careful medical history and physical examination to uncover any subtle supporting signs and symptoms. 1806 Lactic acidosis is an important finding. Hypoglycaemia may be the only sign of a mitochondrial disorder. 1807 Laboratory findings that support a diagnosis of mitochondrial respiratory chain defect include elevated plasma lactate, arterial plasma lactate/pyruvate ratio and arterial α-hydroxybutyrate/acetoacetate ratio. These abnormalities may be exaggerated after a meal or oral glucose load. Urine organic acids, serum carnitine levels or renal tubular function may also be abnormal in disorders of fatty acid oxidation. Confirming the diagnosis of a mitochondriopathy can be Long-chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase presentation is acute liver failure without a seizure disorder. Childhood myocerebrohepatopathy spectrum (MCHS) represents another group of infantile disorders with POLG mutations in which liver failure may occur, along with developmental delay, failure to thrive, lactic acidosis and myopathy. 1844 Mitochondrial cytopathies, particularly Alpers syndrome, are a risk factor for valproate-induced fulminant liver failure, which may obscure the underlying diagnosis. [1845] [1846] [1847] [1848] [1849] Pearson syndrome consists of refractory sideroblastic anaemia, with vacuolization of marrow precursors, and exocrine pancreatic dysfunction. 1850 Patients have large deletions or rearrangements of the mitochondrial genome. 1851 One patient had predominantly hepatic manifestations, such as microvesicular steatosis, massive haemosiderosis and rapidly developing cirrhosis. 1852 This patient had a 7436-bp deletion of the mitochondrial genome in all tissues investigated, compatible with Pearson syndrome. He died within 3 months of birth from liver failure. Haemosiderosis in this patient may have been caused by compound heterozygosity (C282Y and H63D) for mutations of the hereditary haemochromatosis gene HFE, but other infants with Pearson syndrome also have had hepatic haemosiderosis, one of whom was heterozygous for the C282Y mutation. 1853, 1854 Navajo neurohepatopathy (NNH) is an autosomal recessive disorder resulting in sensorimotor neuropathy in full-blooded Navajo Indian children (of the southwestern United States) first described by Appenzeller et al. 1855 in 1976 and further characterized by Singleton et al. 1856 Holve et al. 1857 in 1999 . The latter authors suggested changing the name from 'neuropathy' to 'neurohepatopathy' because liver involvement is an important component of the disease. They described three clinical phenotypes, based on age at presentation and course: an infantile type presenting before 6 months of age with jaundice and failure to thrive; a childhood type presenting between 1 and 5 years of age with liver dysfunction that progressed to liver failure and death within 6 months; and a classic type with variable onset of liver disease but progressive neurological deterioration. Liver histopathological findings in NNH are characterized by multinucleated giant cells, mixed macro-and microvesicular steatosis, pseudoacini, cholestasis, inflammation, bridging fibrosis and cirrhosis in some cases. Ultrastructural findings in four patients have included abnormalities of mitochondria (ringed cristae, swelling and loss of cristae, pleomorphic contour), effacement of canalicular microvilli and accumulation of intracellular bile pigments and fat-containing vesicles. 1857 The pathogenesis of NNH remains poorly understood; however, the genetic defect is mutations in MPV17, which encodes a protein MPV17, in the inner mitochondrial membrane essential for maintaining mDNA. 1858, 1859 Although the infantile form has some similarities to intrahepatic cholestasis disorders, the childhood form suggests a mitochondrial disorder, 1857 and in fact it appears to be in the spectrum of mtDNA depletion disorders. Extrahepatic features may be severe. Hepatocellular carcinoma has been reported in a child with NNH. 1859

These disorders involve mutations in transfer or elongation factors. Typically they present clinically as neonatal liver failure. Transfer factors of note are the ubiquinol cytochrome-c reductase required for assembly of complex II in the OX-PHOS chain, encoded by BCSIL, and Sco1, which is required for assembly of complex IV; these have been described in connection with respiratory chain disorders. Relevant nuclear transfer factors include TRMU, EFG1, EFTs and EFTu, all of which are involved in production of complexes I, III and IV. Mutations in TRMU have been associated with neonatal liver failure 1860 and liver failure in a 2-year-old, who subsequently recovered. 1861 Neonatal hepatitis syndrome (possibly neonatal liver failure) was reported with mutated have reported successful resolution of liver disease with LT. However, in patients with Alpers syndrome or other mitochondriopathies with neurological involvement, LT does not slow the progression of the neurological disease. Careful patient selection is crucial: LT is not indicated for patients with clinically evident extrahepatic disease. 1814, 1815 Genetic mitochondrial disorders Defects originating from mutations in nuclear DNA are inherited as autosomal traits, whereas defects in mtDNA are inherited maternally. Genetic mitochondrial disorders can be classified on the basis of whether the mutation affects a single protein in the mitochondrion or production of mtDNA.
body_text.section: Multiple complex deficiencies related to nuclear translation factor genes

body_text.text: Mutations affecting single proteins in the respiratory chain responsible for oxidative phosphorylation (OX-PHOS) have been described in detail. The usual clinical features are either neonatal liver failure or else severe neonatal hepatitis syndrome. 1803, [1816] [1817] [1818] [1819] [1820] [1821] [1822] Children with mitochondrial respiratory chain defects may be at increased risk of developing hepatocellular carcinoma. 1823 A cytochrome-c oxidase deficiency found in Quebec kindreds may be associated with fatty liver. 1824 Abnormalities in proteins vital to assembly of respiratory chain proteins can also cause liver disease; an important example is neonatal liver failure associated with mutations in SCO1, a protein vital to assembly of complex IV (cytochrome-c oxidase) in the mitochondrial OX-PHOS chain. 1825 GRACILE syndrome is a severe multisystem autosomal recessive disorder with features including cholestasis and hepatic iron overload and lactic acidosis; the mutation is in the gene for the protein BCS1L, which is required for assembly of complex III. 1826 Liver failure caused by BCS1L mutations has also been described. 1827 Disorders of mitochondrial DNA production Another important group of mitochondrial disorders display mtDNA depletion, 1828 which may result in respiratory chain dysfunction. Infantile villous atrophy presenting as intractable diarrhoea with mitochondrial abnormalities in muscle or liver may be an example of such a disease process. 1829, 1830 Various specific gene defects are known to be associated with mtDNA depletion; of these, mutations in deoxyguanosine kinase (dGK or DGOUK) is the abnormality frequently associated with liver disease. [1831] [1832] [1833] [1834] [1835] It may present as a chronic-pattern neonatal liver failure with features similar to perinatal haemochromatosis; it may also present as liver failure later in the first year of life. 1836 Other genes whose mutations may lead to mtDNA depletion include MPV17, SUCLG1, and PEO1/C10orf2, which enclosed the Twinkle DNA helicase. Any of these disorders may present as neonatal liver failure. MPV17 mutations can also present with the chronic liver disease picture of Navajo neurohepatopathy (NNH).
body_text.section: Disorders of respiratory oxidative phosphorylation chain

body_text.text: Alpers syndrome (or Alpers-Huttenlocher syndrome) typically follows a relatively more chronic course and is associated with mutations in DNA polymerase γ. [1837] [1838] [1839] [1840] Mutations in POLG can lead to a diverse spectrum of clinical disease, which may account for some of the heterogeneity of Alpers syndrome. 1841 Patients typically present with a clinical triad of refractory seizures, psychomotor regression and hepatopathy. 1828 They have diffuse cerebral degeneration and progressive neuromuscular deterioration, including ataxia, which leads to death, often in the first 2 years of life. 1842, 1843 The initial presentation is usually neurological, with myoclonic seizures and developmental delay; hepatic involvement is variable but can progress to liver failure over months, and thus frequently heralds death. Rarely, the clinical mitochondrial translation elongation factor G1, encoded by GFM1. 1862 Neonatal liver failure occurred with mutations in the gene TSFM which encodes the elongation factor EFTs. 1863 In the rare case with mutated EFTu, neurological disease dominated the clinical picture, although there was hepatomegaly. 1864
body_text.section: Disorders of respiratory oxidative phosphorylation chain

body_text.text: Fatty acid oxidation disorders represent a broad spectrum of defects in β-oxidation. 1865 Hepatocellular fatty acid metabolism involves complex processes that take place in both the cytoplasm and mitochondria. Long-chain acyl-CoA esters are transported into mitochondria by a carnitine-dependent mechanism; these esters are then metabolized by β-oxidation within the mitochondria. Some of these processes occur at the inner mitochondrial membrane, and others occur within the mitochondrial matrix. Defects in fatty acid oxidation compromise energy production and interfere with formation of ketone bodies; production of dicarboxylic acids becomes a dominant alternate pathway. Hepatic clinical presentation often mimics Reye syndrome. 1812 Disorders likely to cause liver disease include defects in carnitine handling, especially carnitine uptake (OCTN2) and carnitine palmitoyl transferase (CPT1, CPT2) defects, medium-chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase (MCAD) deficiency and long-chain 3-hydroxyacyl-CoA dehydrogenase (LCHAD) deficiency, in that fatty liver of pregnancy occurs in a heterozygote mother carrying a homozygote-affected fetus, and because affected individuals may develop neonatal liver failure or have a delayed hepatic presentation with cholestatic liver disease or cirrhosis. 1866 Diagnosis and treatment of these disorders are difficult. 1812, 1865 Carnitine supplementation may be effective in some disorders and indeed lifesaving in carnitine uptake deficiency (OCTN2 defects). Avoiding prolonged fasting is critically important for all these patients.
Histopathological study of liver and muscle, including examination of ultrastructural features with electron microscopy, may reveal characteristic abnormalities.

Steatosis is typically in the form of fine, cytoplasmic vacuolation around a centrally placed nucleus. Macrovesicular steatosis, defined as a single large droplet displacing the hepatocyte nucleus, often coexists ( Fig. 3.129 in small liver biopsy specimens, overlapping therefore with the histological changes of other metabolic disorders. In such cases the clinical context is critical. Criteria for diagnosing hepatic involvement in Alpers syndrome have been proposed and include microvesicular steatosis and oncocytic change, but these criteria are otherwise not particularly distinctive. 1867 Histochemical examination of cytochrome-c oxidase in liver and muscle may be highly informative. 1868 Some respiratory chain subunits can be detected by immunohistochemistry. Molecular biological techniques permit quantification of mtDNA as well as detection of some deletions and mutations in either nuclear or mitochondrial DNA. Whole-exome sequencing revealed homozygous mutations in MPV17 and SERAC1 in two patients with liver failure. 1869, 1870 Some centres have developed polarographic or enzymatic methods of measuring respiratory chain activity; these and newer diagnostic modalities have been reviewed. [1871] [1872] [1873] If fresh tissue is required for these studies, patients may need to go to centres specializing in mitochondrial disorders. Assays of fatty acid oxidation can be performed in skin fibroblasts, either enzymatically or functionally. 1797 Liver biopsy tissue may be informative regarding respiratory chain defects even in the absence of obvious liver disease. 1874 Histopathological changes in defects of mitochondrial OX-PHOS have been described by numerous investigators.* All have been characterized by microvesicular steatosis (see Fig. 3 .129), variable cholestasis and ductular reaction, variable and sometimes progressive fibrosis and in some cases by cirrhosis (Figs 3.130 and 3.131) . The most detailed descriptions, including ultrastructural studies, were reported in a series of 10 patients by Bioulac-Sage et al. 1875 and in another series of five patients by Morris et al. 1877 Additional histopathological features have included haemosiderosis and an oncocytic appearance of liver cells (from increased number of mitochondria) (Fig. 3.131) . 1878 Changes at the ultrastructural level include pleomorphic mitochondria with few or no cristae and a fluffy, granular matrix 1819, 1875 (Fig. 3.132 ). Morphological findings in Alpers syndrome are similar to those of other mitochondrial cytopathies (Figs 3.133 and 3.134) . Correlation of hepatic changes with those in other organ systems may be useful. 1880 In a recent study of 17 patients with mtDNA maintenance disorders due to MPV17 mutations, steatosis (microvesicular or mixed micro-and macrovesicular) was the most frequent change. 1881 Other changes included fibrosis of variable degree, cholestasis and siderosis. Similar findings were reported by Al-Hussaini et al. 1836 in 11 patients with mitochondriopathies caused by MPV17 (seven patients) or DGUOK (four patients) mutations. In a series of eight patients affected by a defect in mitochondrial synthesis caused by a mutation in the gene encoding for tRNA 5-methylaminomethyl-2-thiouridylatemethyltransferase (TRMU), liver biopsy in a 4-year-old child showed cholestasis, microvesicular steatosis and siderosis. 1882 Cholestasis, fibrosis and small-and large-droplet steatosis were described in an infant with encephalopathy and chronic liver failure caused by a mutation in the gene encoding for the mitochondrial translation elongation factor G1 (GFM1). 1883 In nine patients with fatty acid oxidation disorders, including MCAD and LCHAD deficiency, the histopathological findings were mainly those of microvesicular steatosis. 1884 Amirkhan et al. 1876 reported severe ballooning degeneration of liver cells, mild cholestasis and marked bridging fibrosis. Ultrastructurally, large, oval, membranebound vesicles containing a loose, flocculent material and irregular internal membrane profiles were noted. Large-and small-droplet steatosis was identified in the liver of two infants affected by shortchain enoyl-CoA hydratase (SCEH) deficiency. 1885

Wilson disease is an autosomal recessive disease, with an average incidence of 1 in 30,000 individuals worldwide. The implicated gene, localized to chromosome 13q-14.3, encodes a P-type ATPase which transports copper. Over 500 mutations in this gene have been identified. The symptoms and signs of Wilson disease are the result of copper overload in various organs. The disease is rarely symptomatic before 3 years of age and usually is manifested by signs of liver disease in adolescence. 1886 The diagnosis is occasionally made in patients older than 50. The diagnosis should be considered in any child or adult with hepatocellular disease of undetermined cause, including elevated serum aminotransferases or fatty liver.

Wilson disease may present as a noninfectious recurrent hepatitis or mimic autoimmune hepatitis with findings that include arthropathy, elevated γ-globulin levels and positive antinuclear or anti-smooth muscle antibodies. 1886, 1887 Severe Coombs-negative intravascular haemolysis is usually seen when the presentation is that of acute liver failure (which occurs more often in females); typically such patients have an extremely low serum alkaline phosphatase (ALP) level, comparatively low serum alanine (ALT) and aspartate (AST) aminotransferases and a low serum uric acid level before renal failure. Simple composite indices of laboratory tests have been proposed to facilitate the diagnosis of Wilsonian fulminant hepatic failure. The ratio of serum ALP (in IU/L) to serum bilirubin (in mg/dL) is typically <2 in Wilsonian liver failure. 1888 More recently, in children with Wilsonian hepatic failure, this ratio was <2 IU/µmol; it distinguished paediatric Wilson disease patients from those with acute liver failure from other causes. 1889 A further refinement for adults consists of ALP/total bilirubin (TB) ratio of <4 and AST/ALT ratio of <2.2; together, these ratios can be effective for making the diagnosis Correlation of phenotype with specific mutations (genotype) is difficult in Wilson disease because the vast majority of affected individuals are compound heterozygotes, possessing one copy each of two different mutations. In general, mutations which abrogate production of an intact functional Wilson ATPase protein cause more severe disease, with an earlier and typically hepatic presentation. [1903] [1904] [1905] [1906] Differences in clinical features of various mutations between siblings and even identical twins suggests that other genes or environmental factors are important. 1887, [1907] [1908] [1909] [1910] The only modifying gene thus far identified is apolipoprotein E. 1911 COMMD1 does not appear to act as a gene modifier of ATP7B, 1912, 1913 although there is some suggestion that COMMD1 polymorphism influences age of onset. 1914 The diagnosis is not necessarily simple even when the disease is actively being considered. 1915 In a patient in the age-range 5-50 years who has hepatic disease or typical neurological symptoms, finding serum caeruloplasmin below 5 mg/dL is highly consistent with Wilson disease; finding also a Kayser-Fleischer (KF) ring confirms the diagnosis. Serum caeruloplasmin can be within normal range in as many as one-third of patients. Using receiver-operator curve analysis in patients proven to have Wilson disease by genotyping, Mak et al. 1916 suggest that with the immunoassay, a serum caeruloplasmin below 14 mg/ dL may be informative. (The labour-intensive copper oxidase method is more reliable than immunoassay, which measures apocaeruloplasmin as well as holocaeruloplasmin; its use is generally restricted to research laboratories, but automated techniques are being developed. 1917, 1918 ) Serum caeruloplasmin by itself is not a sufficient diagnostic test for Wilson disease. KF rings are diagnostic, except in patients who have chronic cholestasis of other aetiology. Absence of KF rings occurs in approximately 50% of adult patients with liver disease and thus does not rule out Wilson disease. KF rings may not be present even when there is neurological involvement. 1919 In Wilson disease, the 24-hour urine copper excretion is usually >100 µg (1.6 µmol) and almost always exceeds 40 µg (0.6 µmol). This lower cutoff has proved highly informative in children. 1920 of Wilsonian liver failure, in contrast to serum caeruloplasmin. 1890 Fulminant hepatic failure in Wilson disease may sometimes be precipitated by viral hepatitis. 1891 Neuropsychiatric signs are the predominant presentation in adults but also may be present in up to 50% of teenagers. Tremors, dysarthria, drooling and gait disturbances are frequently observed. Psychiatric manifestations include personality changes and irritability, frank psychosis and depression; some patients may present with only psychiatric symptoms. 1892 Intermittent bouts of jaundice caused by low-grade haemolysis occur in some patients. Bilirubinate gallstones may develop. Ocular findings include the Kayser-Fleischer ring, due to copper accumulation in Desçemet's membrane, and sunflower cataracts, due to copper accumulation in the lens. Both these signs require slit-lamp examination for reliable detection. Relatively common complications include gynaecomastia in males and amenorrhoea in females. Although pregnancy is still possible, repeated spontaneous abortion may occur in women with Wilson disease before diagnosis and treatment. Cardiac complications include ECG abnormalities in 33% of patients. 1893 Ventricular fibrillation is rare, with or without cardiomyopathy. Orthostatic hypotension occurs in 19% of patients, with one-third having an abnormal vascular response. 1893 Urolithiasis is a rare initial presentation. 1894 Renal tubular disease is common and may be either proximal or distal dysfunction. Less well-known complications include hypoparathyroidism, 1895 pancreatic insufficiency from pancreatitis 1896 and rhabdomyolysis.

Although rare in Wilson disease compared to other liver diseases (<20 cases reported), hepatocellular carcinoma occurs in patients of all ages, as young as 9 and 12 years old 1897, 1898 up to the 70s. [1899] [1900] [1901] HCC is a common complication in the Long-Evans Cinnamon rat, the animal model of the disease, but this rat also has hepatic iron overload and abnormalities in p53 function. Cholangiocarcinoma may also occur in Wilson disease. It has been suggested that liver and gastrointestinal malignancies may be more common than often appreciated. 1902 investigated by nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR). 1938, 1939 More than 500 gene alterations in ATP7B have been reported. These are listed comprehensively in various databases, including the HUGO Wilson Disease Database maintained at the University of Alberta (see www.medicalgenetics.med.ualberta.ca/wilson/index.php). The overall pattern of ATP7B mutations (mainly missense) in Wilson disease differs from the ATP7A mutational spectrum found in Menkes disease (large deletions).

Copper disposition in hepatocytes is highly regulated. Available copper in the plasma compartment is bound to albumin or histidine and undergoes reduction to the cuprous form before being transported into hepatocytes by the transmembrane transport hCTR1, encoded by the gene SLC31A1, which appears to span the hepatocellular plasma membrane as a trimer to form a channel. Near the amino terminus, hCTR1 has a copper-binding domain which contains a methionine cluster (MXXXM). 1940, 1941 A second copper transporter, hCTR2, is involved in low-affinity copper uptake by hepatocytes. The action of hCTR1 does not regulate hepatocellular copper homeostasis; however, when copper concentrations are elevated, hCTR1 is degraded. Inside the hepatocyte, little if any copper exists as free copper, apparently because it is a pro-oxidant. Cellular copper toxicity can be prevented by binding to metallothionein and glutathione. Small proteins called 'metallochaperones' mediate delivery of copper to specific sites within the cell. 1942, 1943 CCS1 directs copper to SOD1 in the cytoplasm. Cox17 supplies copper to cytochrome-c oxidase in mitochondria. Sco1 and Sco2 mediate the transfer of copper to subunit II of cytochrome-c oxidase, and other metallochaperones might be involved. ATOX1 transports copper to the Wilson ATPase. ATOX1 has a single CXXC copper-binding motif; it interacts directly with the Wilson ATPase to transfer copper. 1944, 1945 The Wilson ATPase has dual functions: incorporating copper into nascent caeruloplasmin and facilitating biliary excretion of copper. Studies using various model systems have shown that the intracellular location of the Wilson ATPase changes with increased intracellular copper concentration. When intracellular copper concentration is elevated, the Wilson ATPase redistributes to the vicinity of the bile canalicular membrane. 1946 Details of the cellular mechanism of biliary excretion of copper remain unknown. Direct exocytosis into bile of copper from cytoplasmic vesicles in the endosome-lysosome spectrum is an important mechanism. Lysosomal function relating biliary excretion in the Long-Evans Cinnamon (Wilsonian) rat is normal. 1947 Other mechanisms for biliary excretion include a paracellular pathway 1948 and direct transfer of copper bound to glutathione via a bile canalicular transporter. 1949 COMMD1 ('MURR1' renamed, once it became evident that it was part of a family of proteins) is a ubiquitously expressed protein encoded by COMMD1, the gene which may be abnormal in Bedlington terrier hereditary copper toxicosis. The role of COMMD1 in hepatocytes is unclear, but it likely plays a role in the biliary excretion of copper. COMMD1 appears to interact with the Wilson ATPase. 1950 Based on clinical experience, the therapeutic strategy of choice remains chelating agents, particularly D-penicillamine. 1951 In the Long-Evans Cinnamon rat, the drug dissolves copper-rich granules in hepatic lysosomes and prevents the development of fulminant hepatitis. 9 Serious adverse effects may occur with D-penicillamine. Alternatives to D-penicillamine include trientine 1952-1954 and zinc. 1955,1956 Trientine is a chelator with an entirely different structure from that of penicillamine, whereas the mechanism of action of zinc involves competition for copper uptake. It entails induction of enterocyte metallothioneins which have greater affinity for copper than for zinc; consequently, copper taken up by enterocytes is bound and excreted with normal enterocyte turnover. In addition to blocking uptake, this leads to total body depletion of copper by interfering with reabsorption of copper recycled though bile and other fluids

Accumulating data indicate that, if taken as the cutoff for adults, it would improve detection rates for Wilson disease. When penicillamine 500 mg is administered by mouth at the beginning and 12 h later during a 24-hour urine collection, copper excretion >25 µmoles (1587 µg) per 24 h is taken as diagnostic. 1921 This test has been validated only in children, and its sensitivity is not as great as originally thought. Thus its application has become somewhat limited. With compatible pathological changes, a liver copper concentration over 250 µg/g dry weight is diagnostic; however, lower values may be found if the sample is too small or there is variable distribution of parenchymal copper. A lower diagnostic threshold for Wilson disease, based on measurements in a large number of well-characterized patients, has been suggested: 70 µg/g dry weight. 1922 A recent study has shown that when two liver biopsy cores are obtained and one is entirely used for copper estimation, provided that this core weighs more than 1 mg dry weight, a cutoff value of 209 µg/g dry weight has a specificity and sensitivity of 99.4% and 96.1%, respectively. 1923 If the liver copper is in the range of 70-250 µg/g dry weight, further investigations, mainly genetic, are required to exclude or confirm the diagnosis. In the patient who has numerous definite clinical features of Wilson disease, therapeutic intervention should not be withheld until the liver copper concentration is reported. Liver copper <55 µg/g dry weight is within normal range. 1924 Screening the proband's first-degree relatives should include serum AST, ALT, copper and caeruloplasmin determinations, slit-lamp examination for KF rings and basal 24-hour urinary copper determination. Liver biopsy is appropriate for patients with abnormal findings. If the proband's genotype is known, genetic analysis is the more efficient way to screen first-degree relatives.

Mutational analysis can be difficult for several reasons: patients are usually compound heterozygotes; some mutations may be in the promoter region; and mutations must be shown to lead to a nonfunctional Wilson ATPase, a criterion not met currently by all proposed mutations. The role of mutational analysis is critically important in identifying affected first-degree relatives if the genotype of the proband is known. It can also be useful in ethnicities known to have a limited spectrum of ATP7B mutations, for example, in Iceland, Sardinia, the Canary Islands and possibly in northern Europe. However, high-throughput detection methods for analysing DNA are improving rapidly. These include denaturing high-performance liquid chromatography (DHPLC), 1925 automated single-strand conformation polymorphism (SSCP) analysis 1926 and direct sequencing. 1927 A recent study from the United Kingdom of 181 patients with Wilson disease showed that direct sequencing analysis of the entire ATP7B coding region considerably increases the mutation detection rate. 1928 New methods involving microarray techniques have also been reported. 1929 Dietary copper is taken up by the intestinal cell, transported to copper-containing cellular proteins, including metallothionein, or exported from the cell across the basolateral membrane by a process involving the Menkes ATPase (ATP7A). The protein normally resides in the trans-Golgi network and in cell culture moves to the plasma membrane under conditions of high cellular copper concentrations. 1930, 1931 The ATP7A gene is expressed in most tissues except the liver. An X-linked copper deficiency disorder, Menkes disease, results from mutations in this gene. 1932, 1933 The gene abnormal in Wilson disease (ATP7B) shows 56% homology to ATP7A and has 21 exons. [1934] [1935] [1936] It is expressed mainly in the liver. Its product, the Wilson ATPase, has an N-terminus tail comprising six copperbinding sites, each with a cysteine-rich CXXC amino acid motif. Like the Menkes ATPase, this copper-transporting ATPase is also located in the trans-Golgi network. The structure of the Wilson ATPase has been determined by homology mapping using Serca1, the sarcoplasmic Ca 2+ P-type ATPase, as model 1937 ; it has also been draining into the intestinal tract. Zinc treatment may also cause hepatic copper to be stabilized by induction of hepatocellular metallothioneins, and it may have other effects on hepatocellular metabolism. Zinc action is independent of which salt is administered; dosage is calculated as elemental zinc. Compliance remains a major issue because dosage is thrice daily away from food, but effectiveness can be monitored by a decrease in non-caeruloplasmin-bound copper, regression of Kayser-Fleischer rings, improving liver tests and 24-hour urinary excretion of copper. On chelator treatment, this is expected to run in the 3-8 µmol/day range, but on zinc it should diminish toward normal (<1.2 µmol/day as target), as a reflection of decreased total body copper load. Antioxidants (mainly vitamin E) may be used as adjunctive therapy. Dietary therapy includes avoidance of liver, shellfish, mushrooms, chocolate and nuts, but dietary treatment alone will not control the disease.

Liver transplantation is reserved for patients unresponsive to medical therapy or with fulminant hepatic failure. One-year survival is excellent, about 85-90%. 1957, 1958 A recent study from France showed a similar survival rate at 5, 10 and 15 years. 1959 Living-donor transplantation from an individual obliged to be a heterozygote with one ATP7B mutation (e.g. a first-degree relative) is physiologically acceptable. 1960, 1961 LT for neurological complications is highly controversial and generally cannot be recommended. [1962] [1963] [1964] Ammonium tetrathiomolybdate is an experimental therapy mainly used in patients with CNS involvement. 1965 There has been some success with combination therapy with zinc and trientine administered individually in a temporally dispersed pattern every 5-6 h through the day (for clinically severe disease, usually decompensated cirrhosis). 1966 This intensive drug regimen is best reserved for induction therapy: those who improve can usually be switched to a single-drug regimen after several months. Introduction of ATB7B into the Long-Evans Cinnamon rat by recombinant adenovirus-mediated gene delivery restores normal hepatic copper secretion into the serum and bile. [1967] [1968] [1969] The pathological effects of Wilson disease are considered to be directly related to the accumulation of copper in the brain, cornea, liver and kidneys, but pathogenetic mechanisms are unknown. Oxidative stress appears to play an important role because copper is a redox-active pro-oxidant. In severe liver disease requiring LT, extensive functional abnormalities in hepatic mitochondria have been detected. 1970 Detailed studies in a mouse model of Wilson disease indicate that mitochondrial dysfunction is limited to complex IV of the OX-PHOS chain. 1971 The findings may also provide additional rationale for the use of antioxidants in Wilson disease. Recent observations show that copper interferes with nuclear receptor function, principally with RXR, not only in Wilson disease but in severe cholestasis with hepatocellular retention of copper. 1972 When Wilsonian fulminant hepatic failure occurs, evidence of massive hepatocellular apoptosis can be found. 1973 Patients presenting with acute hepatitis are rarely biopsied. According to Scheinberg and Sternlieb, 1887 the livers of these patients show ballooning of hepatocytes, apoptotic bodies, cholestasis and a sparse lymphocytic infiltrate. Typically, the biopsy in the precirrhotic stage is characterized by variable portal inflammation, moderate anisonucleosis, focal necrosis, scattered sinusoidal apoptotic bodies and moderate to marked steatosis 1974 (Figs 3.135 and 3.136 ). Lipofuscin accumulates in periportal areas, and some of the granules are large, irregular in shape and vacuolated. 1974 Kupffer cells may be slightly enlarged and laden with haemosiderin, presumably as a result of the acute haemolytic crises that may complicate the disease. There is a progressive increase in periportal bile ductular reaction and fibrosis. Variable numbers of inflammatory cells, chiefly lymphocytes and plasma cells, are seen in the connective tissue of portal areas. Changes indistinguishable from those of chronic hepatitis due to other aetiologies, in particular autoimmune hepatitis, may be seen [1975] [1976] [1977] (Figs 3.137 and 3.138) . In our experience, helpful differential clues in the diagnosis of Wilson disease (in addition to portal inflammation and interface hepatitis) include steatosis, periportal glycogenated nuclei, moderate to marked copper storage (Fig. 3.139) and Mallory-Denk bodies in periportal liver cells.

Cytochemically demonstrable copper is usually confined to periportal hepatocytes in the precirrhotic stage of Wilson disease. With the use of special stains (Timm stain) and electron probe microanalysis, Goldfischer and Sternlieb 1978 showed that in young, asymptomatic patients, copper is diffusely distributed in the cytoplasm of hepatocytes. In slightly older patients who exhibit early symptoms or signs of the disease, the metal is both diffusely distributed and intralysosomal, whereas in patients with advanced disease, all the copper is confined to lysosomes (Fig. 3.139) . The various staining methods for the demonstration of copper in tissue sections have been reviewed by Lindquist 1979 and Irons et al. 1980 In our experience and that of others, 1980 the p-dimethylamino benzylidene rhodanine method gives the most reproducible results (Fig. 3.139) ; both it and the rubeanic acid method are specific for copper. There is a linear relationship between microscopic evaluation of the stain and actual tissue copper levels. 1980 Copper-binding protein can be stained by of Wilson disease. Early in the disease, copper is mainly in the cytosol and is highly soluble, particularly in poorly buffered formalin; lysosomal copper-binding protein may also be absent. Failure to detect hepatocellular copper histochemically is particularly common in children presenting with Wilson disease. Of note, children with primary sclerosing cholangitis may have periportal deposits of copper and copper-binding protein on liver biopsy specimens, and marked hepatic copper overload mimicking Wilson disease has been described in children with MDR3 deficiency. 679 Both caeruloplasmin and metallothionein have been demonstrated immunohistochemically in the liver in patients with Wilson disease. Graul et al. 1984 found no difference in the pattern of staining of caeruloplasmin in the livers of patients with Wilson disease and normal adults or neonates. Studying the distribution of metallothionein in Wilson disease, Nartey et al. 1985 found that in sections with minimal tissue damage, there was intense cytoplasmic staining for metallothionein in liver cells, whereas in sections with extensive necrosis and fibrosis, there was both nuclear and cytoplasmic staining.

The Wilson ATPase has been examined in the human liver by immunoblotting, IHC and double-label confocal scanning laser microscopy. 1986 It is present predominantly in trans-Golgi vesicles in the pericanalicular area, but relatively small amounts of the protein appear to localize near the canalicular membrane, consistent with a dual function of the protein in holocaeruloplasmin synthesis and biliary copper excretion. Defective trafficking within hepatocytes is a functional characteristic of some mutations.

The cirrhosis of Wilson disease is usually macronodular but can be mixed or even micronodular in type. 1974 Microscopically, it is characterized by varying-sized nodules separated by fibrous septa that may be wide or very thin, with minimal ductular reaction and variable inflammation (Fig. 3.140 ). All changes in the precirrhotic stage are also seen in the cirrhotic liver. In addition, Mallory-Denk bodies can be identified frequently at the periphery of the cirrhotic nodules ( Fig. 3.141 ). Variable numbers of apoptotic bodies may be present. Clusters of large hepatocytes with a granular eosinophilic cytoplasm (oncocytic or oxyphil cells), resulting from an increased number of mitochondria, are often seen. The distribution of copper is quite variable, with some of the cirrhotic nodules containing a lot and others containing little or none. 1974 Copper is rarely demonstrable in Kupffer cells or portal macrophages in the cirrhotic stage, but it is frequently encountered in cases of submassive or massive orcein in Wilson disease and other conditions (e.g. chronic cholestatic disorders), [1980] [1981] [1982] [1983] as well as by aldehyde fuchsin and Victoria blue. The granules also stain with a variety of stains for lipofuscin that is aggregated in the same lysosomes. 1974 Negative staining for both copper and copper-associated protein does not exclude the diagnosis Mallory-Denk bodies appear as masses of randomly oriented and densely packed fibrils (each ~15 µm in diameter), which are partially rimmed by bundles of finer filaments but are not limited by membranes. 1991, 1992 Lipolysosomes, which constitute 1-2% of the lipid droplets in hepatocytes in Wilson disease, may represent a nonspecific alternate route for the mobilization of excess lipid from hepatocytes. 1993 Importantly, ultrastructural mitochondrial changes in Wilson disease cannot be considered pathognomonic; although exceedingly rare with cholestatic liver disease, such changes are found with mtDNA depletion disorders. 1994 However, the presence of abnormal mitochondrial morphology in young children with Wilson disease, in whom copper studies are not clearly diagnostic, may help to confirm the diagnosis. One ultrastructural study of liver tissue from a family of nine siblings suggested that mitochondrial changes may not be sufficient for detecting a presymptomatic affected person. 1995 In our experience with genetically confirmed Wilson disease, mitochondrial changes occur early and can be informative.

The long-term effects of D-penicillamine therapy on the structure and function of the liver in patients with Wilson disease were reported by Sternlieb and Feldmann. 1996 Liver biopsy specimens from seven patients, obtained before and after 3-5 years of therapy, were studied Davies et al. 1987 also noted the presence of copper in hepatic parenchymal and mononuclear phagocytic cells in 11 patients with Wilson disease who, although presenting with fulminant hepatic failure, were cirrhotic. Another case has been described in detail. 1988 Ultrastructural findings in the precirrhotic stage of Wilson disease have been described in detail. 5, 1887, 1989 Of these, the mitochondrial changes are the most distinctive and pathogenetically significant and include heterogeneity of size and shape, increased matrix density, separation of inner from outer membranes, enlarged intercristal spaces and various types of inclusions (Fig. 3.144 ). Sternlieb 1990 also described three distinct patterns of structural abnormalities of the mitochondria in hepatocytes of 40 of 42 asymptomatic and 8 of 32 symptomatic patients with Wilson disease before therapy. There was no correlation between the type of abnormality and the patient's age, hepatic copper concentration, degree of hepatic steatosis or the serum aminotransferase levels. There was, however, a high degree of fraternal concordance, suggesting that the structural changes are genetically determined. Alterations in Wilson disease, other than those affecting mitochondria, include an increase in the number of peroxisomes (which may appear heterogeneous and denser and larger than normal), lipofuscin granules and multivesicular bodies. by EM and stereology. The characteristic mitochondrial abnormalities encountered in the hepatocytes of untreated patients were less pronounced or disappeared after treatment in five of the seven patients. Simultaneously, relative mitochondrial volume, surface density of the external mitochondrial membranes and number of these profiles per unit area increased, whereas abnormal elevations of serum aminotransferases returned to normal.

This hepatic copper toxicosis has been most prevalent in the Indian subcontinent. 1997 Indian childhood cirrhosis (ICC), or a liver disorder strongly resembling it, has been reported from numerous countries, including cases from the United States. 710, 1998 ICC should not be confused with North American Indian cirrhosis (or cholestasis), which is caused by mutations in the cirhin gene. 710, 711, 713 In India, ICC was a significant cause of morbidity and mortality among children younger than 5 years. 1999 The incidence in India has declined sharply after recognition of the role of copper overload in its pathogenesis. 2000, 2001 Epidemiological and clinical aspects of ICC are well reviewed. 1999, 2002 The age range is from 6 months to 5 years, with a peak around 2 years. In 30-50% of patients with ICC, there is a history of sibling disease and death, but Mendelian inheritance is not apparent. Evidence against a genetic background for the disease is its apparent absence in South Asian expatriates in the United Kingdom, Africa and North America. 2003 Three clinical stages of ICC have been recognized 2002 : (1) an early stage with an insidious onset characterized by disturbances of appetite and bowel movement, slight enlargement of the liver and occasional jaundice; (2) an intermediate stage characterized by irritability, minimal jaundice, marked hepatomegaly, splenomegaly and occasionally, subcutaneous oedema, ascites and susceptibility to infection; and (3) a late stage with increasing jaundice, hepatosplenomegaly and progression to hepatic failure and death.

Hepatic histopathology in ICC 2004 has been described in detail. 1999, 2002, 2004 The earliest changes are ballooning degeneration and focal necrosis, followed by formation of Mallory-Denk bodies, 1992 sometimes with neutrophilic satellitosis. Steatosis is conspicuously absent (Fig. 3.145) . The mesenchymal reaction is characterized by inflammatory cell infiltration (lymphocytes, histiocytes, neutrophils and a few plasma cells), variable periportal ductular reaction, progressive fibrosis and eventually development of a micronodular cirrhosis (Fig. 3.146) . Regenerative activity appears absent. 2004 ICC is associated with marked hepatic copper overload (Fig. 3.147) . The copper storage has been demonstrated histochemically (by staining tissue sections with orcein for copper-binding protein and using the rhodanine method for copper) and by quantitative techniques such as atomic absorption spectrophotometry. 2000, 2001, 2005, 2006 It is now generally accepted that the copper storage is directly responsible for the histopathological lesions in ICC. The copper accumulates first in periportal hepatocytes and then extends toward the terminal hepatic venules. Orcein stain may also have diagnostic utility. 2007 In 1983 , Tanner et al. 2008 proposed that increased dietary copper (from copper-contaminated milk stored in brass and copper containers) could be of aetiological significance in ICC. Subsequently, O'Neill and Tanner 2009 demonstrated experimentally that copper (but not zinc) is avidly taken up from brass and bound to casein, from which copper is completely removable by picolinate chelation. They concluded that milk is an effective carrier of copper from a brass utensil to the infant enterocyte. Several studies of clinical recovery, improved long-term survival and even reversal of the hepatic histological lesions by penicillamine therapy in infants with ICC provide evidence for a direct cytopathic effect of copper. [2010] [2011] [2012] Cases of an ICC-like disease caused by chronic ingestion of water with

Primary immunodeficiencies are a group of rare inherited disorders characterized by one or more abnormalities of the immune system. Many of these disorders are X-linked, and males are more likely to be affected. They manifest clinically with infections and/or malignancy, and dysregulated immunity in the form of autoimmunity, autoinflammation and/or allergy. Infections of the upper and/or lower respiratory tract or gastrointestinal (GI) symptoms such as diarrhoea are common clinical presentations. 2020 Recurrent infections affecting multiple sites, of prolonged duration and unusual intensity, and by unusual organisms should raise suspicion of a primary immunodeficiency (PI). Susceptibility to specific organisms is a characteristic of some PIs. Acquired disorders or other conditions such as drug-related immunosuppression, human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection or cystic fibrosis need to be excluded in the first instance. Liver involvement in patients can occur for various reasons: directly as a result of the PI, or as a consequence of medical therapy or in connection with haematopoietic cell transplantation. The most common manifestation is sclerosing cholangitis, often related to Cryptosporidium infection. Liver abscesses, granulomatous inflammation, autoimmune hepatitis and nodular regenerative hyperplasia have also been described. The most recent classification 2021 divides the PI disorders into nine categories (Table 3 .7). The reader is referred to this classification; a more detailed description of these disorders is beyond the scope of this chapter. Only the main conditions associated with liver involvement are discussed here.

Chronic granulomatous disease (CGD) is characterized by recurrent purulent infections caused by bacteria (usually catalase-positive) or fungi. The onset is generally before 1 year of age, although milder forms may present in adulthood. Marked lymphadenopathy, hepatomegaly and splenomegaly are common findings. 2022 Liver abscess occurred in approximately one-third of 268 patients with CGD, 2023 and Staphylococcus aureus was the most frequently isolated organism. In CGD, antimicrobial activity of phagocytes is impaired due to the lack of reactive oxygen species, or oxidative burst, normally produced by NADPH oxidase. The most common X-linked form of CGD represents 70% of all cases. 2024 Autosomal recessive forms are considerably rarer. CGD is caused by mutations in the cytochrome-b β-subunit (CYBB) gene, which maps to chromosome Xp21, 2025 cloned in 1986, 2025 and encoding the gp91-phox (phagocyte oxidase) protein, a necessary component in the NADPH oxidase pathway. 2026, 2027 It is currently classified in the category of defects in intrinsic and innate immunity. 2021 Mutations in the CYBB gene responsible for CGD have been described, permitting prenatal diagnosis. 2028 Assessment of defective granulocyte function by flow cytometry can be used in neonates. 2029 Patients are screened for CGD by the nitroblue tetrazolium dye reduction assay. 2030 Although some CGD patients respond to interferon-γ therapy, this has not been a useful long-term treatment. 2031 Radical surgery is recommended for liver abscess. 2032 BMT was helpful in one case. 2033 Granulocyte transfusions from healthy donors given G-CSF subcutaneously and dexamethasone orally 12 hours before collection have helped to eradicate occurrence of invasive aspergillosis. 2034 Recently, stem cell transplantation with a reduced-intensity conditioning protocol has been followed by full donor chimerism and normalization of superoxide production. 2035 Gene therapy, including ex vivo protocols, are promising 2036 and the subject of intense investigation in murine models. [2037] [2038] [2039] The characteristic pathological features of CGD are the granulomatous response to infection and the widespread accumulation of lipofuscin pigment in reticuloendothelial cells [2040] [2041] [2042] [2043] (Fig. 3.148 A) . high levels of copper ('hepatic copper toxicosis') are discussed in Chapter 12. The decline in the incidence of ICC since feeding practices have been changed to avoid the use of copper vessels for infants and young children, and the continued remission of affected children after discontinuing penicillamine once sufficient hepatic copper has been removed, suggest that environmental factors are important in the development of ICC. Developmental and genetic factors cannot be entirely excluded. 2013 Studies indicate that COMMD1, the gene abnormal in Bedlington terrier hereditary copper toxicosis, does not play a role in either ICC or Tyrolean infantile cirrhosis. 2014 A disorder resembling ICC has been described in Indian children 5-15 years old. 2015 The disorder differs from classic ICC because of its late clinical presentation and relatively slow progression of liver damage. It differs from Wilson disease in that serum caeruloplasmin is in normal range or elevated and 24-hour basal urinary copper excretion is only moderately increased (0.8-2.5 µmol/24 h). Liver biopsy shows no steatosis; micronodular cirrhosis may be present. It is not clear whether this is a different disorder or a milder presentation of ICC. Its genetic basis is not known.

Clinically and pathologically indistinguishable from ICC, endemic Tyrolean infantile cirrhosis was reported from a circumscribed rural area of Western Austria between 1900 and 1974. 2016 Some 138 infants and young children died from the disease. The frequency of the disease peaked between 1930 and 1960; it has disappeared from that area since 1974. The inheritance was apparently autosomal recessive. Cow's milk, contaminated with copper from untinned copper or brass vessels, may have contributed to the development of copper toxicosis. Replacement of untinned copper cooking utensils by modern industrial vessels eradicated the disease. Tyrolean infantile cirrhosis is believed to be an ecogenetic disorder requiring the involvement of both genetic and environmental factors for its manifestation. 2016, 2017 It is not an allelic variant of Wilson disease. 2018 Histopathological changes include micronodular cirrhosis with copper overload in the most severely affected children. 2019

Common variable immunodeficiency (CVID) is characterized by impaired B-cell function with hypogammaglobulinaemia, although T-cell function may also be deficient. CVID is currently classified in the category of 'predominantly antibody deficiencies' with the understanding that this term includes several clinical phenotypes caused by various genetic and environmental factors. 2021 Recurrent upper and lower respiratory tract infections are a common manifestation, and autoimmune and lymphoproliferative disorders are common complications. Immunoglobulin replacement therapy is the mainstay of treatment. Nodular regenerative hyperplasia has been described in 5% of 261 patients with CVID, with some patients developing portal hypertension. [2049] [2050] [2051] Daniels et al. 2052 described a mild chronic hepatitis picture in a cohort of 10 CVID patients. A granulomatous component is also common. 2050, 2052 Murakawa et al. 2053 described two patients with a severe enteropathy and hepatitis leading to liver failure and LT. Hepatosplenic T-cell lymphoma mimicked juvenile SLE in a CVID patient. 2054

The largest study with the rare, X-linked hyper-IgM syndrome (XHIM), as reported by the Registry of Primary Immunodeficiencies of the European Society for Immune Deficiency, included the clinical and immunological features and outcome of 56 patients. The defect is caused by mutations in the gene encoding for CD40 ligand, located on chromosome Xq 26.3-27. It is currently classified in the category of 'immunodeficiencies affecting cellular and humoral immunity' . 2021 XHIM is a cellular immunodeficiency characterized by disruption of multiple cellular interactions (e.g. T cells-B cells, T cellsmacrophages). Patients are unable to mount IgG, IgA and IgE responses to T-cell-dependent antigens and lack germinal centres, but their ability to produce IgM is preserved. Infections are the most prominent clinical manifestations of XHIM. Upper and lower respiratory tract infections (the latter frequently caused by Pneumocystis carinii), chronic diarrhoea and liver involvement (both caused by Cryptosporidium infections) are common. 2055 Many patients have chronic neutropenia associated with oral and rectal ulcers. An example of cryptosporidiosis in a 15-year-old male with XHIM (diagnosed Small granulomas consist of rings of mononuclear cells which surround an area of homogeneous eosinophilic material and are associated with many plasma cells and a few giant cells. 2044 Confluent granulomas may show larger areas of necrosis and suppuration. Palisading granulomas with central necrosis and associated giant cells were noted in four of seven cases reported by Nakhleh et al. 2045 Special stains for microorganisms are usually negative, unless the granulomas are caused by fungi. 2046 The pigmented histiocytes have a light-tan colour and are PAS positive, argentophilic, sudanophilic (in frozen sections) and autofluorescent (Fig. 3.148 B) . The accumulation of the pigment is thought to be a secondary phenomenon. 2047 In the liver, most of the lipofuscin is found in clusters of greatly hypertrophied portal macrophages or Kupffer cells. Portal areas are infiltrated by plasma cells and lymphocytes, and there may be minimal to moderate fibrosis. A hepar lobatum-like cirrhotic process was described in one patient. 2048 Varying numbers of granulomas and microabscesses may be scattered within the parenchyma, and there may be slight to moderate portal inflammation and fatty change (Fig. 3.149) . haemopoietic stem cells from HLA-matched related or unrelated donors is feasible and curative if performed before significant infections and organ damage occur. 2060 Successful sequential liver and BMT has been reported. 2056, 2059 Histiocytic and haemophagocytic syndromes
body_text.section: Liver disease in X-linked hyper-IgM syndrome

body_text.text: Familial haemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis (FLH), a fatal inherited form of haemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis (HLH) syndrome, is a defect in cell-mediated cytotoxicity characterized by the overwhelming activation of T lymphocytes and macrophages. It is currently classified as a disease of 'immune dysregulation' . 2021 FLH is a heterogeneous autosomal recessive disorder; one causative gene (PFR1, localized to chromosome 10q21-22) encoding for perforin, a cytotoxic effector protein, has been identified in a subset of patients. 2061, 2062 at age 18 months) is illustrated in (Fig. 3.150) ; ERCP revealed sclerosing cholangitis. In the series of Levy et al., 2055 19.6% of patients had sclerosing cholangitis and 55% of those patients had concomitant cryptosporidiosis. In another series of 20 children from 16 families, 45% had sclerosing cholangitis. 2056 Liver tests are persistently abnormal, with a median AST of 117 IU/L and a γ-glutamyltransferase (GGT) of 182 IU/L in one series. 2056 Patients with XHIM have developed carcinomas of the liver (hepatocellular carcinoma or bile duct carcinoma), pancreas or gallbladder, and also of neuroectodermal endocrine cells. 2055, 2057, 2058 The tumours were fatal in eight of nine cases in one series 2057 and in most instances were preceded by a chronic cholangiopathy and/ or cirrhosis.

Survival in XHIM is poor, 20% at 26 years in the series of Levy et al. 2055 The treatment of choice is intravenous immune globulin (IVIG). 2055 LT has been associated with a high rate of recurrence of cryptosporidiosis, although long-term survivors have been reported. 2055, 2059 Stem cell transplantation is curative, but its success is hampered by conditioning-related liver complications (e.g. veno-occlusive disease, graft-versus-host disease). 2056 Allogeneic Genes implicated are important for the exocytosis of cytotoxic granules which contain perforin and granzymes and induce apoptosis on entering the target cell and therefore are important for the downregulation of the immune response. 2063 The disease is characterized by fever, anorexia, irritability and pallor in infancy and early childhood, although onset in adolescents and adults up to the fifth decade has been reported. 2064 FLH can usually be distinguished from other infantile causes of histiocytosis by the absence of skin lesions and the high incidence of CNS involvement. Hepatosplenomegaly is typically prominent early, and jaundice may develop later. 2065 Extremely abnormal coagulation studies reflect low fibrinogen levels and thrombocytopenia, but other coagulation factors are normal. Neurological symptoms may develop from histiocytic involvement of the brain. Although clinical manifestations may remit temporarily, the disease is eventually fatal. The diagnosis is based on identifying erythrophagocytosis by histiocytes in bone marrow biopsy material or occasionally on liver biopsy. Perforin expression by peripheral lymphocytes, assessment of 2B4 lymphocyte receptor, and natural killer (NK) cell activity have been proposed as rapid tests to assist differentiating FLH from HLH subtypes, therefore highlighting patients with a poor prognosis who may benefit from BMT. 2061 In an autopsy series, haemophagocytosis was most often observed in the spleen, lymph nodes and bone marrow. 2066 Hepatic involvement is characterized by hypertrophy of Kupffer cells and portal macrophages, which manifest striking erythrophagocytosis (Fig. 3.151 ), but this may be inconspicuous or even absent. 2067 In 19 patients, hepatic histology showed portal and sinusoidal infiltrates of CD3, CD8, granzyme B+ lymphocytes admixed with CD68, CD1a−ve histiocytes, with haemophagocytosis in all specimens. 2068 Portal areas may show lymphohistiocytic infiltrates with a predominance of T lymphocytes, in a pattern reminiscent of chronic hepatitis (Fig. 3.151 ). In some cases there is striking enlargement of endothelial cell nuclei and perivenous erythropoiesis resembling graft rejection. 2067 Other changes include mild hepatocellular damage in the vicinity of the lymphohistiocytic infiltrates, variable cholestasis and epithelioid granulomas. 2067

In haemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis (HLH), also known as infection-associated (reactive) haemophagocytic syndrome, there is proliferation of morphologically nonmalignant histiocytes showing phagocytosis of haemopoietic cells, with associated fever and pancytopenia. Clinical severity ranges from the incidental observation during infection or findings at autopsy that macrophages throughout the body are large and activated to the full-blown haemophagocytic syndrome (HLH), which includes fever, hepatosplenomegaly, coagulopathy and various cytopenias. 2069 HLH can manifest as acute liver failure. 2070, 2071 It can also present as neonatal liver failure; since FLH often shows very high serum ferritin levels, distinction from so-called neonatal haemochromatosis can be difficult. 2072, 2073 Tissue specimens are critical in distinguishing these two diseases because LT is contraindicated in FHL, whereas it might be lifesaving in neonatal haemochromatosis. 2073 Epstein-Barr virus infection (virus-associated haemophagocytic syndrome) remains the most frequent association with HLH, but since the first report in 1979, many other viruses 2074, 2075 and other infectious agents have been incriminated. 2076, 2077 There are a few reports of simultaneous development of HLH and SLE. 2078 Patients with rheumatic disorders, especially juvenile chronic arthritis, appear particularly at risk; the condition is often referred to as macrophage activation syndrome in this setting. 2079, 2080 Haemophagocytic features are often seen in livers of patients with acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS) (Fig. 3.152 ). The haemophagocytic syndrome may also develop in diseases other than infections, such as lymphoma and disseminated carcinoma. 2081, 2082 In about one-fifth of patients, according to a large recent series of 103 cases, there was no association with an underlying specific disorder. 2083 Reactive (secondary) HLH and macrophage activation syndrome manifest as a massive cytokine and chemokine release, mostly TNFα, IFN-γ, soluble interleukin-2 (IL-2) receptor, IL-6 and other cytokines whose levels in the blood may have a prognostic value. 2084 This cytokine profile distinguishes HLH from the primary familial conditions in which an underlying genetic defect is identified. In contrast, NK-cell function is preserved in the reactive form but defective in the inherited syndromes. 2069 Histologically, there is infiltration of the portal tracts with normalappearing histiocytes, lymphocytes and plasma cells. Sinusoidal changes are prominent and include sinusoidal congestion and increase in size and number of Kupffer cells, which display prominent haemophagocytosis. In a series of 30 patients with haemophagocytic syndrome, haemophagocytosis was seen in all patients. 2085 In 16 patients, erythrophagocytosis was associated with intracytoplasmic B A accumulation of haemosiderin or bile. Haemophagocytosis was not seen in portal tracts. The Kupffer cells are only weakly stained with PAS, a feature helpful in distinguishing this change from a response to necroinflammatory conditions, in which the Kupffer cells are often strongly PAS positive. 2086 Additionally, Kupffer cells frequently show siderosis, possibly related to the erythrophagocytosis itself or to blood transfusions. 2086 Correlation is lacking between the degree of peripheral cytopenia and the degree of hepatic haemophagocytosis. 2086 Immunohistochemical findings on liver tissues have provided direct evidence for the involvement of activated CD8+ lymphocytes through the production of IFN-γ, and of macrophages through the haemophagocytosis and production of both IL-6 and TNFα, irrespective of the associated condition. 2087 Prendki et al. 2088 have proposed a reduced perforin-positive/CD3-positive lymphocyte ratio as an indicator of haemophagocytosis.

This rare disorder (previously termed 'histiocytosis X') is characterized by infiltration of various tissues and organs by Langerhans cell histiocytes. Langerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH) primarily affects bone, but lung, skin and lymph node involvement may be seen. Hepatic involvement is also well recognized, especially in children, with sclerosing cholangitis occurring in 10-15% of those with multisystemic involvement, 2069, 2089 whereas LCH confined to the liver appears to be very unusual. 2090, 2091 Kaplan et al. 2092 reported nine cases of hepatobiliary LCH and found another 85 acceptable cases in the literature. Ages ranged from 7 days to 62 years (median, 18 months), with a 2:1 female preponderance. Hepatosplenomegaly, jaundice, liver dysfunction and ascites were the most common clinical presentations.
