Gross findings vary with the stage of disease and type of hepatic involvement. Large aggregates of Langerhans cells, eosinophils and other inflammatory cells may form tumour-like masses. Infiltration of large ducts may lead to grossly visible cystic dilation and rupture. Other cases show irregularly distributed biliary fibrosis, while a biliary cirrhosis is already present in a few cases. 2092 The diagnostic feature in all cases is the presence of Langerhans cells. 2093 They typically have an abundant pink cytoplasm; lobulated, coffee-bean-shaped or contorted nuclei with a fine chromatin pattern; and no discernible nucleoli (Figs 3.153 and 3.154 ). In the vast majority of cases the Langerhans cells are accompanied by varying numbers of eosinophils (Fig. 3.155) , lymphocytes, neutrophils, plasma cells, non-Langerhans histiocytes and occasional multinucleated giant cells. Immunostains were useful in confirming the nature of the Langerhans cells by using antibodies to S-100 protein, CD1a 2094,2095 (Fig. 3.156 ) and CD31. 2096 CD1a is important as activated Kupffer cells may acquire S-100 positivity. 2097 Langerin is coexpressed with CD1a in LCH, 2098 but it should be assessed in isolation only with caution because langerin-positive CD1-negative cells are present in normal liver. 2098, 2099 The lectin receptor CD207/langerin is useful, but it seems to mark dermal cells unrelated to Langerhans cells. 2100 Typical Birbeck granules may be found ultrastructurally in Langerhans cells.

Many patients with disseminated disease have aggregates of Langerhans cells that range from granulomatous foci to large nodules in the liver, with abundant eosinophils in these lesions 2092, 2101 (Figs  3.157 and 3.158) . The majority of cases show some degree of active bile duct infiltration, injury and destruction by Langerhans cells (Figs 3.159 and 3.160) ; this is the most characteristic feature of hepatic involvement. Small and medium-size bile ducts are often infiltrated by the Langerhans cells, with displacement of the epithelial cells. Some ducts may be entirely replaced by masses of Langerhans cells within the pre-existing basement membrane. Injury to large bile ducts by the Langerhans cells may produce cystic dilation and rupture with a xanthogranulomatous inflammatory response.

Concentric periductal fibrosis is a prominent feature in the majority of cases. When the ductal infiltration by Langerhans cells in all cases clinically or morphologically diagnosed as sclerosing cholangitis in children; however, extrahepatic manifestations of LCH will generally help in reaching the correct diagnosis.

The aetiology and pathogenesis of LCH remain undetermined. Evidence suggests an immune dysregulation with uncontrolled clonal proliferation of dendritic cells exhibiting Langerhans cell characteristic 2103 and of bone marrow rather than epidermal origin. 2104 A low susceptibility to apoptosis 2105 and high level of diverse cytokines production by Langerhans cells, 2106 with sustained stimulation of T cells, lead to the unique pathological picture, which combines features of a neoplasm and chronic inflammation. 2107 The demonstrated clonality of LCH does not prove the neoplastic nature of the lesion. The frequent detection of BRAF V600E or MAP2K1 mutations, in addition to clonality, 2108, 2109 suggests that LCH is a neoplasm. 2104 Viral proteins and DNA sequences of human cytomegalovirus, 2110 Epstein-Barr virus 2111 and human herpesvirus 6 2112 have been detected by immunohistochemistry (IHC), in situ hybridization (ISH) and PCR in LCH tissue, but whether these represent causal agents or opportunistic infections secondary to immune dysregulation remains uncertain. is pronounced, there is often marked surrounding fibrosis with demonstrable Langerhans cells in the fibrous tissue. Ducts at a distance from the Langerhans cell lesions may also show epithelial injury and periductal fibrosis, consistent with a secondary sclerosing cholangitis.

Changes caused by the bile duct lesions include periportal ductular reaction, ductopenia (Fig. 3.161) , chronic cholestatic features with periportal cholate stasis ('pseudoxanthomatous change') and deposition of copper and copper-binding protein. Some degree of periportal or bridging fibrosis is common and progresses to a biliary cirrhosis (Fig. 3.162 ). It must be noted that needle biopsy specimens may show changes caused by a distal cholangiopathy only, without demonstration of Langerhans cells, despite direct LCH infiltration of the major bile ducts. 2102 The differential diagnosis of LCH in childhood includes other forms of sclerosing cholangitis: primary sclerosing cholangitis, with or without chronic inflammatory bowel disease, as well as sclerosing cholangitis associated with immunodeficiency (see Chapter 9). In view of the morphological overlap with LCH, it is recommended that immunostains for S-100 and CD1a and langerin be performed

This disorder was first reported by Rosai and Dorfman 2126 and subsequently reviewed by Foucar et al. 2127 It usually affects patients between ages 10 and 20 years. In addition to massive enlargement of cervical and other lymph nodes, there is fever, leukocytosis, elevated ESR and hyperglobulinaemia. The course is protracted, lasting 3-9 months, but the prognosis is usually excellent. The disease can involve extranodal sites, including soft tissues, the oral cavity, lower respiratory tract, genitourinary system and the liver. Involvement of the last three organs is associated with a poor prognosis. 2127 Liver involvement is uncommon. 2128 Lauwers et al. 2129 studied 11 patients in whom the disease involved the intestinal tract (five patients), liver (five) and pancreas (one). Most patients also had evidence of disease in other extranodal sites, as well as in one or more lymph node groups.
body_text.section: Sinus histiocytosis with massive lymphadenopathy (Rosai-Dorfman disease)

body_text.text: In the review of Foucar et al., 2127 hepatomegaly was noted in 27 of 157 cases. Four patients had histopathological evidence of hepatic involvement. In most instances, gross evidence of disease was lacking, except for one case in which a 1.5-cm, well-circumscribed white nodule was found in the right lobe of the liver. 2127 The hallmark of Rosai-Dorfman disease is the proliferation of histiocytes, which have an abundant cytoplasm and normal-appearing nuclei ( Fig. 3.163 A and B) . The cells are seen in portal areas and in hepatic sinusoids. They display avid leucophagocytosis, but can also phagocytose RBCs. According to Eisen et al., 2130 Although patients with LCH have a good overall prognosis, 2113 approximately 20% of patients with multisystem involvement will show a progressive disease course despite treatment. 2114, 2115 In particular, patients with hepatic involvement have a worse prognosis with survival at 3 years of 96.7% for those without, but only 51.8% for those with liver involvement. 2116 In patients with cirrhosis and end-stage liver failure due to LCH sclerosing cholangitis, orthotopic liver transplantation (OLT) has been proven a successful therapeutic option, 2102, 2117, 2118 with 67% of patients living long-term after surgery (median follow-up, 5.8 years; range, 2.1-7.5 years). A significant number of LCH patients have developed post-transplant lymphoproliferative disorders, apparently related to a higher incidence of refractory rejection. 2119 Disease recurrence in the liver allograft occurs in about 30% of patients and seems easily managed. 2119, 2120 Chemotherapy protocols are chosen on the basis of disease distribution and extent. 2104 Juvenile xanthogranuloma, a histiocytic disorder, is primarily but not exclusively seen throughout the first two decades of life and principally as a solitary cutaneous lesion. It can manifest with multiple small systemic lesions (xanthoma disseminatum), in which case the liver can occasionally be involved. The infiltrating cells are factor XIIIa, fascin and CD68 and CD163 positive among various markers, 2121 but S-100, langerin and CD1a negative. 2098, 2122 Touton cells are rarely seen in extracutaneous sites. There appears to be an overlap with LCH because skin lesions with characteristics of juvenile xanthogranuloma may be found in children with LCH. 2069 Erdheim-Chester disease is a rare, non-Langerhans type of histiocytosis with xanthogranulomas. It appears to be neoplastic. 2123 Liver involvement is uncommon; biliary tract obstruction has been reported. 2124, 2125 named SBDS, which encodes a ribosomal protein involved in ribosomal and other cellular processes. 2149, 2150 Disease-causing SBDS mutations are found in approximately 90% of patients.
body_text.section: Sinus histiocytosis with massive lymphadenopathy (Rosai-Dorfman disease)

body_text.text: SDS was differentiated from cystic fibrosis by Shwachman et al. 2151 in 1964 . The syndrome may begin in utero; the average birth weight is 25% of normal. By age 6 months, patients are below the fifth percentile. The apparent causes of the poor growth, pancreatic insufficiency and fat malabsorption may improve with age. [2152] [2153] [2154] Haematological abnormalities occur in 100% of patients: neutropenia in up to 95%, thrombocytopenia in up to 70% and anaemia in over 50%. 2153, [2155] [2156] [2157] The neutropenia can be intermittent, and abnormal chemotaxis may be present temporarily. SDS is currently listed in the congenital defects of phagocyte number, phagocyte function or both in the most recent classification of primary immunodeficiencies (see Table 3 .7). 2021 Bone marrow biopsy may reveal hypoplasia with fat replacement and myeloid maturation arrest. 2158 EM examination of cartilage reveals material retained in the rough endoplasmic reticulum. 2159 At least half the patients have metaphyseal dysostosis. 2159 Hepatomegaly is present in 15% of patients, and AST and ALT are elevated in up to 60% of patients; the liver tends to improve with age. 2160, 2161 Adults with SDS were found to have hepatic microcysts on MRI. 2161 Veropalumbo et al. 2162 reported SDS as mimicking autoimmune hepatitis and coeliac disease in two children.
body_text.section: Sinus histiocytosis with massive lymphadenopathy (Rosai-Dorfman disease)

body_text.text: The pancreas in SDS shows replacement of exocrine tissue by fat with preservation of the endocrine islets. 534, 2151 According to Burke et al., 2163 the degeneration of pancreatic exocrine tissue is progressive. Cardiomegaly and testicular fibrosis were reported in one case. 2164 The liver shows variable steatosis. 534, 2151 Some of the patients in the series of Bodian et al. 534 also had portal fibrosis or 'cirrhosis', but detailed histological descriptions of the hepatic changes were not reported.
body_text.section: Sinus histiocytosis with massive lymphadenopathy (Rosai-Dorfman disease)

body_text.text: Some SDS patients have responded to treatment with G-CSF. 2165 There is an increased risk of haematological malignancies similar to those that occur with Fanconi anaemia. 2166 Nineteen patients with myelodysplastic syndrome and leukaemia have been reported. 2167 BMT has been attempted; only two of eight patients are disease free, including one who has required LT for veno-occlusive disease. 2168, 2169 Familial and genetic nonalcoholic steatohepatitis and cirrhosis Differentiation is required between familial occurrence of diseases in the nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) spectrum where an acquired defect of insulin disposition is the primary abnormality, possibly enhanced by genetic predisposition, and genetic disorders that involve disordered insulin disposition, thus producing a NAFLDlike hepatic disease (see Chapter 5) . Familial occurrence of nonalcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH) with or without cirrhosis, or with cryptogenic cirrhosis, was reported by Struben et al. 2170 in 18 members of eight kindreds. Fifteen (83%) of the 18 were obese, and 11 (31%) had type 2 diabetes mellitus. The occurrence of these disorders within kindreds suggested a common pathogenesis and possible genetic risk. Other cases of familial cirrhosis 2171, 2172 or cryptogenic cirrhosis with a family history of unexplained liver disease (19% of patients in series of Caldwell et al. 2173 ) have been reported. Susceptibility to NAFLD has been shown to be associated with polymorphism in the patatin-like phospholipase domain-containing 3 (PNPLA3) gene, encoding adiponutrin. [2174] [2175] [2176] Glucose regulatory protein (GCKR) has been associated with fatty liver in obese children, 2177 and transmembrane 6 superfamily member 2 (TM6SF2) polymorphisms may also be important in children. 2178 Various other genes have been implicated. 2179 Various genetic disorders produce a NAFLD-or NASH-like liver disorder. Steatohepatitis 2180 and cirrhosis 2181 have been reported in associated with lysosomal activity (lysozyme, α1-antitrypsin, α1antichymotrypsin); antigens associated with early inflammation (Mac-387, 27E10); antigens commonly found on monocytes, but not tissue macrophages (OKM5, Leu-M1); and activation antigens (Ki-1, receptors for transferrin and IL-2). They are negative for CD1a and langerin. 2098 The cells thus appear to be true, functionally activated macrophages derived recently from circulating monocytes. 2130
body_text.section: Sinus histiocytosis with massive lymphadenopathy (Rosai-Dorfman disease)

body_text.text: Neonatal lupus erythematosus (NLE) 2131-2136 may cause neonatal hepatitis syndrome. Hepatic involvement may occur with NLE, which is caused by passage of maternal anti-Ro/SSA and anti-La/SSA antibodies, or occasionally U1-ribonucleoprotein, across the placenta. Fetal tissues expressing Ro and La antigenic determinants may be damaged. The heart, skin and liver are most likely to be involved, rarely with thrombocytopenia and leukopenia. 2133, 2137 Congenital heart block is the most important cardiac manifestation. Most infants develop a rash, which typically resembles the rash of subacute cutaneous lupus erythematosus but may have other features, in the newborn period or some weeks later. In approximately 10% to 25% of patients, hepatic disease occurs, usually typical neonatal hepatitis syndrome resembling idiopathic neonatal hepatitis. 2134, 2138, 2139 Occasionally, liver involvement is severe enough to suggest extrahepatic biliary tract obstruction, with acholic stools and nondraining hepatobiliary scan. 2140, 2141 Increased iron accumulation in the liver was found on liver biopsy in the first infant recognized as having NLE with liver involvement, 2138 and subsequently an infant was reported with severe liver disease showing features of perinatal haemochromatosis. 2142 Transient elevation of serum aminotransferases only, or unexplained isolated conjugated hyperbilirubinaemia in the perinatal period and later presentation at 2-3 months of age with transient serum aminotransferase increase, is recognized. 2143 In most infants the liver disease resolves completely between 6 and 12 months of age, as the maternal antibodies are degraded. Mild fibrosis was found in one child with NLE on repeat liver biopsy.

The diagnosis of NLE is difficult in the absence of congenital heart block or typical skin rash. Some infants have only transient jaundice and myocarditis with abnormal ECG. The diagnosis should be suspected if the mother is known to have SLE or Sjögren syndrome. Frequently, however, the mother is asymptomatic with respect to rheumatological disease. Routine methods may fail to detect anti-Ro and anti-La in the infant; these studies should be performed at as young an age as possible. Very high titres of antinuclear antigen (ANA) in the infant may be caused by NLE. Deposits of associated antibodies (anti-Ro and/or anti-La) may be found in affected liver tissue by immunofluorescence. 2144 Most infants with unexplained neonatal hepatitis syndrome do not have NLE. 2145 One infant was reported with neonatal hepatitis syndrome and transplacental transfer of antimitochondrial antibodies. 2146 The disease mechanism is similar to that of gestational alloimmune liver disease (GALD) in that transplacental passage of antibodies causes neonatal liver disease with iron accumulation; however, NLE is milder and tends to be self-limited.

Shwachman-Diamond syndrome (SDS) is an autosomal recessive disorder 2147 characterized by pancreatic exocrine insufficiency, bone marrow dysfunction and skeletal abnormalities. 2148 The Shwachman locus has been mapped to chromosome 7q11.21. Disease-associated mutations have been identified in the gene associated with SDS, by Ruchelli et al. 2204 Arai et al. 2210 have suggested that megakaryocytederived TGFβ1 is one of the candidates in the activation of hepatic stellate cells leading to the hepatic fibrosis. High levels of N-terminal peptide of procollagen III, type IV collagen and hyaluronic acid were found in the serum of a lethal case at 5 days of life. 2212 The liver disease generally accompanies a haematological disorder unique to Down syndrome called transient abnormal myelopoiesis, transient myeloproliferative disorder or transient leukaemia. 2213, 2214 The condition consists of a clonal proliferation of blast cells exhibiting megakaryocytic features and historically associated with a high rate of spontaneous remission. Its true incidence remains to be determined. A number of cases may occur as an incidental finding of abnormal cell counts and blast cells in the peripheral blood in an otherwise well child, but in approximately 20% of cases the disease is manifest as hydrops fetalis and liver or multiorgan failure resulting in death. Of those children who enter a spontaneous remission, 13-33% have been found to develop acute megakaryoblastic leukaemia (AMKL), usually within the first 3 years of life, which if left untreated is fatal. In trisomy 21, fetal haemopoietic progenitors acquire N-terminal truncating mutations in the key megakaryocyte-erythroid transcription factor GATA1. Mutations are found in blast cells of both transient myeloproliferative disorder and megakaryoblastic leukaemia, 2215 suggesting that additional as yet unidentified (epi)genetic mutations are required for progression to AMKL. 2216 A recent multicentre survey suggests a good response of leukaemic patients to early therapy with standard-dose intensive chemotherapy, including cytarabine and anthracyclines. 2217 Neonatal hepatitis syndrome can occur in children with Down syndrome in the absence of transient abnormal myelopoiesis or leukaemia. Generally, these children also have congenital heart disease or GI abnormalities. 2218 This population study suggests that the incidence of neonatal hepatitis syndrome in children with Down syndrome is unexpectedly high (3.9%) and that conjugated hyperbilirubinaemia is more severe in those with transient abnormal myelopoiesis.

The syndrome of fatty liver and encephalopathy, first described in 1963 by Reye et al., 2219 based on postmortem findings in 17 children from Australia, was soon recognized to have a worldwide distribution. 2220 The observation of an association between aspirin and Reye syndrome, 2221 subsequent advice from the Surgeon General of the United States that the use of salicylates be avoided in children suffering from influenza or varicella, and confirmatory prospective studies 2222, 2223 have been followed by a steady decline in the incidence of 'classic' or 'idiopathic' Reye syndrome worldwide. 2224, 2225 At present, all patients presenting with a 'Reye-like syndrome' are presumed to have an inherited metabolic disorder unless there is clear evidence of the classic combination of a flu-like illness and salicylate therapy. In addition, metabolic disorders were subsequently diagnosed in many patients who had survived an acute disease attributed to Reye syndrome. 2226 Consequently, the following account may be in part historical because it is largely based on data collected when knowledge of metabolic disorders and their diagnostic tools were limited. Nevertheless, it seems likely that Reye syndrome as such exists and may reflect a pharmacogenetic or immunogenetic susceptibility in those who do not have a demonstrable metabolic disorder. Which drugs or environmental toxins and which viruses may contribute to development of classic Reye syndrome remain a conundrum.

With few exceptions, 2227, 2228 idiopathic Reye syndrome occurs almost exclusively in children, has no sex predilection, and is usually preceded by a resolving viral illness, particularly influenza B or varicella. Initial symptoms include vomiting (usually repetitive), lethargy patients with partial lipodystrophy. NASH is also reported in children with Bardet-Biedl syndrome and in both children and adults with Alström syndrome, [2182] [2183] [2184] in whom cirrhosis may occur. Steatohepatitis (sclerosing hyaline necrosis) was also described in a patient with Bloom syndrome. 2185 This autosomal recessive disorder is characterized by a normally proportioned but strikingly small body size, characteristic facies, photosensitive skin lesions, immunodeficiency and marked predisposition to a variety of cancers and some evidence of disordered insulin action. Likewise, there are multiple reports of marked hepatic steatosis (but no steatohepatitis or cirrhosis) in patients with Dorfman-Chanarin syndrome, an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by marked hepatic steatosis, ichthyosis and variable CNS and muscle involvement. 2186, 2187 Other rare disorders with NAFLD-like liver disease include mulibrey nanism 2188 and Cohen syndrome. 2189 Hepatotoxicity and other known genetic/metabolic diseases that can cause fatty liver, such as Wilson disease and cystic fibrosis, must be excluded because treatment is radically different. 2190 Although these diseases clearly can manifest a 'nonalcoholic' steatosis, they are neither NAFLD nor NAFLD-like.

Congenital total lipodystrophy is characterized by near-absence of adipose tissue, severe insulin-resistant diabetes hyperlipidaemia, hepatomegaly, muscular hypertrophy, hypertrichosis and acanthosis nigricans. 2191 Inheritance is believed to be autosomal recessive. A disease locus has been identified on chromosome 11q13, 2192 with some families having linkage to 9q34. 2193 An association with peripheral pulmonary artery stenosis was reported in three children by Uzun et al. 2194 Four subtypes are now described, associated with mutation in the AGPAT2, BSCL2, CAV1 and PTRF genes. 2195 The liver is enlarged and grossly yellow or light yellow-brown in colour. Light microscopic changes, described in a number of case reports, [2196] [2197] [2198] [2199] [2200] [2201] [2202] [2203] include steatosis and periportal fibrosis, with portalto-portal bridging. Ductular reaction was noted in several patients with congenital total lipodystrophy. 2200 Cirrhosis was present in some patients. [2196] [2197] [2198] 2201 Hepatocytes in one patient were described as 'plant-like' with prominent cell walls, a pale vacuolated cytoplasm and pale, centrally placed nuclei; the presence of fat and glycogen was demonstrated in the cytoplasm of liver cells by special stains.

Ultrastructural abnormalities have been described in several reports. 5, 2198, 2199, 2201 In addition to numerous lipid droplets, there are many lysosomes containing variable quantities of lipofuscin and lipolysosomes. 5 Peroxisomes are said to be increased 2198, 2200 or reduced in number, 5 and they contain dense matrix granules. Mitochondria are abnormally shaped and contain distinctive, elongated, crystal-like matrical inclusions that adopt various geometric configurations. 5 They possibly represent cholesterol or other lipid material. Partial lysis of swollen and irregular mitochondria was described in one patient with congenital total lipodystrophy. 2196

Severe liver disease can occur in Down syndrome, or trisomy 21 mosaicism. [2204] [2205] [2206] Stillbirth, hydrops fetalis or neonatal liver failure at or within a few weeks of birth are recognized presentations. [2207] [2208] [2209] [2210] [2211] Morphologically, there is diffuse fibrosis surrounding reactive bile ductules and residual hepatocytes. 2204 Extensive hepatic necrosis has also been observed. In most livers a large number of megakaryocytes or megakaryoblasts, staining positively for factor VIII-related antigen and binding to Ulex europaeus 1, as well as other haematopoietic elements, are present in the sinusoids. 2204, 2207 Parenchymal iron deposition of variable degree was noted in most of the cases studied and changes in mental status. Hepatic dysfunction can be overlooked since the liver is minimally enlarged, and there is no jaundice or splenomegaly. Subsequent symptoms and signs are predominantly neurological and terminate in coma. Seizures sometimes occur, particularly in younger children with hypoglycaemia. Most patients have received multiple medications, including aspirin, for the symptoms of the viral illness. Initial laboratory screening tests disclose elevated serum aminotransferase levels, hyperammonaemia and coagulopathy. Although the liver disease is benign and transient, the encephalopathy (secondary to a hypoxic/metabolic insult resulting in cerebral oedema) can be life threatening and can result in permanent neurological disability. 2220 Early diagnosis based on clinical findings and liver biopsy, along with meticulous supportive care, results in decreased mortality and morbidity.

Grossly, liver biopsy or autopsy specimens from patients with Reye syndrome are yellow. The major histopathological finding is diffuse microvesicular steatosis. 2229 In the typical case the hepatocytes are swollen and packed with multiple small vacuoles (Fig. 3.164) ; neutral lipid can be demonstrated in frozen sections stained with Oil Red O or Sudan Black B (Fig. 3.165 A) . The lipid droplets are consistently smaller in the perivenular zone than in other areas. 2229 Vacuolization may not be evident in biopsy material obtained less than 24 hours after the onset of encephalopathy, even though appropriately stained frozen sections will reveal an abundance of fat. Nuclei of the liver cells are enlarged and centrally located. Mitotic activity of variable degree may be seen. Hepatocellular necrosis is generally absent or is mild and spotty. Periportal necrosis is occasionally found, 2230 preceded by ballooning degeneration of periportal hepatocytes. Variation in the severity of glycogen depletion of liver cells in early biopsies correlates with other histological measures of severity, and with the occurrence of hypoglycaemia, severity of encephalopathy at admission and the mortality rate. Portal inflammation is either minimal or absent. Cholestasis is rarely observed; in some instances it may be related to an associated pancreatitis. 2231 Reduction of succinic dehydrogenase and cytochrome oxidase activities (and other mitochondrial enzymes) has been demonstrated by enzymatic stains and is most helpful in confirming the diagnosis 5 ( Fig. 3.165 B) .

At the ultrastructural level, the most dramatic changes are seen in hepatocellular mitochondria, 5, 2232 which are enlarged and misshapen. The degree of enlargement correlates to some extent with the stage of encephalopathy. 2232 The severity of Reye syndrome may also be correlated with lucency of the mitochondrial matrix and loss of matrical dense bodies (Fig. 3.166 ). Other mitochondrial changes in initial hepatic biopsy specimens from patients who die or have severe neurological sequelae include a decrease in size and number of cristae. There may be an increase in the amount of smooth endoplasmic reticulum with varying degrees of dilation, and 50% of hepatic biopsy specimens reveal flocculent peroxisomes. 2233 Microvesicular steatosis has been reported in several inherited metabolic disorders and in drug-and toxin-induced liver injury, such as with tetracycline, nucleoside analogues, aflatoxin, pyrrolizidine alkaloids, margosa oil, hypoglycin A, pentanoic acid and valproic acid (see Chapter 12) . Aspirin toxicity may mimic Reye syndrome. 2233 At the light microscopic level, the liver findings in children with fatal salicylate intoxication resemble those of Reye syndrome, 2234 but the ultrastructural changes appear to be different. 2232 Animal models of Reye syndrome with encephalomyocarditis virus 2235 or influenza B 2236 infection, and the spontaneous 'Reye-like syndrome' in BALB/cByJ mice usually associated with coronavirus infection, have been described. 2237 In another murine model, treatment with 4-pentenoic acid produced a Reye-like syndrome. 2238

First described as acute febrile mucocutaneous lymph node syndrome in 1967, 2239 Kawasaki disease usually affects children, more rarely adults up to the sixth decade of life. 2240 It is an acute vasculitis of unknown aetiology. It can result in the formation of coronary artery perhaps aspirin has proved beneficial, the former seemingly reducing the frequency of coronary artery abnormalities. 2245, 2246 Corticosteroids have a role in Japanese children at high risk of resistance to IVIG treatment. 2247, 2248 Male gender, abnormal liver enzymes, low albumin and platelets and the percentage of leukocytes/lymphocytes have been found as risk factors for treatment nonresponse. 2249 Patients less than 1 year old or more than 9 years old at diagnosis may have poorer outcomes. 2250 Atypical cases not fulfilling the conventional diagnostic criteria have a much higher mortality rate, perhaps because of the lack of therapy. 2251 The hepatobiliary complications of Kawasaki disease have been underestimated. Biochemical abnormalities of liver involvement are frequently encountered. 2252 The most common problem results from a hydrops of the gallbladder, which is detectable by ultrasonography, with an incidence ranging from 2.5% to 13.7%, and may be a risk factor for the development of coronary aneurysm. 2253, 2254 Prolonged pain has been attributed to poor emptying of the gallbladder. 2255 The patients have right upper quadrant pain sometimes associated with vomiting. A majority have hepatomegaly and at times a palpable gallbladder. Resolution usually occurs in 4 weeks. Perforation is a rare complication. Cholangitis with bile duct injury and ductular reaction has been observed on liver biopsy in three cases. 2256 Pathological findings at laparotomy include inflammation of the gallbladder, with or without evidence of vasculitis, and occasionally cystic duct obstruction due to inflammatory oedema or lymph node compression. Portal vein blood flow may be impaired. 2257 In addition to vasculitis, inflammation has been noted in autopsy cases in the oral cavity (including ductal structures), small bowel and the pancreas (including the ducts) 2258 ; acute cholangitis or bile duct damage has also been observed. [2258] [2259] [2260] Mild bile ductular reaction has been noted, but to date, ductopenia has not been a feature. Cholangitis may be associated with sinusoidal neutrophilic infiltrates (Figs 3.167 and 3.168) , and proliferation and swelling of Kupffer cells are frequently seen.

Similarities between Kawasaki disease and leptospirosis have been raised; although the Weil-Felix reaction may be positive, direct tests for leptospirosis are negative. 2261 The close resemblance of fatal cases to infantile periarteritis nodosa has also been emphasized in several studies. 2258, 2262 Affected vessels include the larger coronary arteries and splenic, renal, pulmonary, pancreatic, spermatic, periadrenal, hepatic and mesenteric vessels. Microscopically, the vessels show periarterial inflammation, necrosis and destruction of the media and intimal inflammation. Lesions of varying stages can be observed aneurysms in approximately one-quarter of patients who do not receive IVIG within 10 days of illness. 2241 The diagnostic criteria, formulated by an international panel for a complete diagnosis of Kawasaki disease, include the presence of unexplained fever more than 5 days and four of five main clinical features: (1) changes in extremities such as acute erythema of palms and soles, oedema of hands or feet and subacute periungual peeling of fingers and toes in weeks 2-3; (2) polymorphous exanthema; (3) bilateral bulbal conjunctival injection without exudate; (4) changes in lips and oral cavity: erythema, lips cracking, strawberry tongue, diffuse injection of oral and pharyngeal mucosae; and (5) cervical lymphadenopathy >1.5 cm, usually unilateral. 2242 'Incomplete' Kawasaki disease is defined by two or three of the previous five criteria plus coronary artery disease. GI signs and symptoms include abdominal tenderness, vomiting, diarrhoea, bloody stools and mild jaundice. Hepatobiliary complications comprise hepatosplenomegaly, mild ascites and hydrops of the gallbladder. Jaundice is a rare presentation. 2243 The laboratory data include abnormal ECGs, neutrophil leucocytosis with a shift to the left, thrombocytosis and an increased ESR. Mortality in boys during the first 2 months of the illness is twice the average rate for the disease generally. 2244 Coronary aneurysms and myocarditis occur in 10-20% of patients, with a higher incidence in boys. 2245 Thus Kawasaki disease is a major cause of acquired heart disease in children. Early therapy with high-dose IV γ-globulin and reviewed. 2283 The liver has been reported to be histologically normal in some patients 2286, 2287 or to show nonspecific changes such as an increased glycogen content, 2286,2288 mild fatty change 2288 or haemosiderosis. 2289 Haemosiderosis, both hepatocellular and reticuloendothelial, was also present in the cases reported by Donohue and Uchida 2281 and Ordway and Stout 2290 in combination with other changes. Both these reports described multiple small nodules in the liver that were composed of large, pale, foamy hepatocytes containing much glycogen and a little fat, with occasional fusion of cells and formation of syncytial masses. Ordway and Stout 2290 interpreted these foci as regenerative nodules (Figs 3.169 and 3.170) . Intrahepatic cholestasis has been reported in several cases 2283 and bile ductular reaction in one case. 2290 in different vessels in the same patient and in different areas of the same type of vessel (e.g. coronary arteries), suggesting that the inflammatory process continues over the course of the disease. Aneurysmal dilation of coronary and other vessels (brachial, iliac, renal and pulmonary) may occur. 2258, 2263 Marks et al. 2264 reported the case of a 4-year-old boy with a hepatic artery aneurysm that caused obstructive jaundice.

Other than leptospirosis, Propionobacterium acnes, 2265 toxin-secreting Staphylococcus aureus, 2266 HIV, 2267 Epstein-Barr virus, 2268 parvovirus B19, 2269 Yersinia infection 2270 and an unusual response in a susceptible individual to an infectious agent such as the measles virus 2271 have all been proposed as causes of Kawasaki disease but are not supported by hard data. Activated T lymphocytes play a key role in the disease mechanism, and genetic susceptibility loci have recently been identified. [2272] [2273] [2274] [2275]

The salient features of Aarskog-Scott syndrome include short stature and facial, digital and genital malformations. 2276 The disease is X-linked 2277 and has been ascribed to mutations in the FGD1 gene, implicated in skeletal and neuronal development. 2276, 2278, 2279 One reported patient had a slightly elevated total serum bilirubin, and needle biopsy of the liver revealed haemosiderosis and a micronodular cirrhosis. 2280

A rare disorder, leprechaunism (also called Donohue syndrome) is characterized by a grotesque elfin facies with a flat nasal bridge and flaring nostrils, thick lips and large low-set ears. Patients have hirsutism, enlargement of the breasts and external genitalia, motor and mental retardation, failure to thrive and progressive marasmus. Death occurs before 2 years of age. 1030, [2281] [2282] [2283] The disease is autosomal recessive. Patients have mutations in the high-affinity insulin receptor. Two novel mutations have been identified recently. 2284 Rabson-Mendenhall syndrome is a milder form of the disease. Most patients, however, die by adolescence from intractable ketoacidosis. 2285 A consistent pathological feature of the syndrome in females is follicular maturation of the ovaries with cyst formation. Some patients have hyperplasia of the islets of Langerhans and severe malformations of the brain and heart. Other associated findings have been

Of the several known forms of oculocutaneous albinism, only two involve the liver: Chediak-Higashi syndrome and Hermansky-Pudlak syndrome. Both are listed in the 'diseases of immune dysregulation' category of the latest classification of primary immunodeficiencies (see Table 3 .7). 2021

Patients with this syndrome are distinctive, with a light-cream to slate-grey skin and hair that has a metallic, frosted-grey sheen. Other findings include photophobia, squint, nystagmus and decreased pigment in the retina. Patients have recurrent infections, most often by gram-positive organisms. A progressive neuropathy, usually noted at about 5 years of age, involves cranial and peripheral nerves. Rarely, adults with a less severe form of the disease have findings consistent with either spinocerebellar degeneration or Parkinsonian disease. Hepatosplenomegaly is common, particularly in the accelerated phase of the disease, 2291 which is heralded by fever, lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly, pancytopenia, hyperlipidaemia and coagulopathy. Tissue infiltrates consist of benign-appearing histiocytes showing haemophagocytosis, plus lymphocytes and plasma cells which, in the liver, are found in portal areas and sinusoids. 2292 Diagnosis is based on the presence of characteristic giant, eosinophilic, peroxidase-positive inclusions in leukocytes that do not degranulate. The disease is autosomal recessive and is caused by a defect in the lysosomal trafficking gene LYST, which is essential for the function of NK cells. 2293 Treatment has included chemotherapeutic agents, particularly during the accelerated phase, but the only cure has been BMT. 2292

Hermansky-Pudlak syndrome is characterized by oculocutaneous albinism, a mild bleeding diathesis caused by a storage pool platelet defect, and widespread deposition of ceroid pigment in cells of the reticuloendothelial system. 2294, 2295 Complications include pulmonary fibrosis, renal failure, cardiomyopathy and a granulomatous colitis. 2294 The disease is autosomal recessive and genetically heterogeneous, 2296, 2297 resulting from defects in genes affecting the function of multiple cytoplasmic organelles. 2298 Involvement of the liver in Hermansky-Pudlak syndrome is limited to the presence of a light-tan, granular pigment in hypertrophied Kupffer cells and portal macrophages (Fig. 3.171) . The pigment has all the characteristics of ceroid or lipofuscin, being PAS positive and diastase resistant, sudanophilic and argentophilic, and it reveals bright-yellow autofluorescence when viewed by ultraviolet microscopy (Fig. 3.172) . Ultrastructurally, the pigment is granular, intermingled with lipid and bounded by a single membrane. Occasionally, it shows a fingerprint pattern of concentric light and dark bands with a periodicity of approximately 20 nm. 2299

Gross abnormalities and congenital anomalies of the biliary system are discussed here; congenital anomalies of the vascular structures of the liver are discussed in Chapter 11. Vascular abnormalities in the placenta may lead to neonatal liver disease. Fetal thrombotic vasculopathy has been associated with severe neonatal liver disorders, typically with some degree of neonatal liver failure; although one had a neonatal Budd-Chiari lesion, most infants show only neonatal hepatitis syndrome. 2300

Absence of the liver is incompatible with life. It has been reported in stillborn fetuses, usually in association with other severe anomalies. 2301 The association with omphalocele has been interpreted as the result of defective development of the septum transversum. 2302 are relatively frequent findings, particularly on the inferior surface of the liver. In one patient an accessory lobe adherent to the left liver lobe had its own gallbladder. 2326 They are connected to the liver by hepatic tissue or by a mesentery containing branches of the portal vein, hepatic vein and hepatic artery, and a bile duct. 2327 Intrathoracic accessory lobes, with their vascular supply perforating the diaphragm, have been reported. 2328 Accessory lobes may rarely require surgical intervention because of their large size, torsion of a pedicle or the presence of other associated defects. 2329 Pedunculated HCC may arise in accessory lobes. Focal nodular hyperplasia has also been described. 2330 Ectopic hepatic tissue Ectopic hepatic tissue may be found in the suspensory ligaments of the liver, lung, wall of the gallbladder, splenic capsule, retroperitoneal space, adrenal gland and greater omentum. [2331] [2332] [2333] [2334] [2335] [2336] [2337] A unique case of ectopic liver in the placenta was reported by Willis. 2338 In most patients, the hepatic tissue in these ectopic sites is microscopically normal, but when the liver is abnormal (fatty change, chronic hepatitis, cirrhosis), the ectopic liver tissue reflects the same changes. 2339, 2340 Infantile haemangioendothelioma arising in an ectopic intrathoracic liver has been reported. 2332 Twenty-three cases of HCC, mostly from Japan, have arisen in ectopic livers. 2340, 2341 Heterotopias Most of the so-called adrenal heterotopias are actually examples of adrenal-hepatic fusion. Dolan and Janovski 2342 made a distinction between 'adhesion' and 'fusion' on the basis of presence or absence of a capsule interposed between the two organs. In both types, there was a marked diminution or complete absence of medullary tissue. The fusion is unilateral and is not associated with clinical evidence of adrenal impairment. It was found in 9.9% of unselected autopsy cases in one study. 2343 The incidence was much higher in older age-groups, suggesting that the condition may be an aging phenomenon. There is a single description of hepatolienal fusion. 2344 Adrenal neoplasms may arise in these adrenal rests (see Chapter 13) .

Pancreatic heterotopia in the liver is rare (Fig. 3.173 ). In the case reported by Ballinger, 2345 an islet cell carcinoma arose in the aberrant pancreatic tissue. Retention cyst has been recorded in an obstructed duct within the heterotopic pancreatic tissue. 2346 Foci of exocrine pancreas in the liver of a 41-year-old patient with cirrhosis were

Absence of the left lobe of the liver has been described, 2303 in one case associated with floating gallbladder. 2304 Radin et al. 2305 collected 19 cases of absence of the right lobe from the literature. The anomaly was associated with biliary tract disease in 12 patients, portal hypertension in seven patients, other congenital anomalies in four patients, but it was an incidental finding in five patients. Inoue et al. 2306 reported a case of hypogenesis of the right hepatic lobe associated with portal hypertension and reviewed 31 other cases of agenesis or hypogenesis in the Japanese literature. Injury to bile ducts occurred at cholecystectomy in a case of right lobe agenesis. 2307
This rare anomaly has been associated with suprahepatic 2308 or retrohepatic 2309 gallbladder, the latter complicated by hepatolithiasis and liver abscess.

Complete atrophy of the left lobe has been found in children 2310 when there is concomitant thrombosis of the left branch of the portal vein and left hepatic vein; clinically evident portal hypertension in such a condition is rare. 2311 A similar process affecting the right lobe is rarer. In adults, atrophy of the left lobe is also more common than atrophy of the right lobe, and it is associated with portal vein thrombosis; thrombosis of the corresponding hepatic vein may not be present or not detected. 2312 Although a bile duct lesion may be present, the portal vein obstruction seems to be dominant. Segmental or lobar atrophy is frequently observed in primary sclerosing cholangitis.

In situs inversus totalis or abdominalis, the liver is found in the left hypochondrium, with the falciform ligament coursing from the left anterior margin toward the umbilicus. Hepatolithiasis has been reported in a patient with situs inversus. 2313 Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) is rare. 2314 Adenocarcinoma of the distal common bile duct was reported in a 68-year-old woman with total situs inversus. 2315 A liver in a left or transverse position is one of the anomalies which may be associated with biliary atresia. 53 Varying amounts of hepatic tissue may be displaced into congenital diaphragmatic hernias or omphalocoeles. Hepatic-pulmonary fusion has been described in association with diaphragmatic hernia. 2316 Hepatic tissue was present in 3 of 19 omphalocoeles studied by Soper and Green. 2317 The liver tissue may be the seat of nonparasitic cysts 2318 and may be detached from the rest of the liver. 2319 Several cases of hepatic herniation through defects in the diaphragm have been reported. [2320] [2321] [2322] A unique case of a supradiaphragmatic right liver lobe and gallbladder has been reported. 2323 Partial eventration of the right hemidiaphragm is a congenital lesion caused by aplasia or hypoplasia of part of the musculature of the diaphragm, with resultant bulging of the affected portion from intra-abdominal pressure. 2324 The underlying portion of the liver prolapses into the diaphragmatic pouch, where it may become strangulated.

Riedel lobe is a tongue-like caudal projection from the right lobe of the liver, which may be palpated in the right upper quadrant. In the 31 cases of Reitemeier et al., 2325 all the patients except one were women, their ages ranging from 31 to 77 years. Supernumerary lobes

Several patients with absence of the common hepatic duct have been described. [2355] [2356] [2357] They presented with obstructive jaundice in very early infancy and at operation were found to have no proximal biliary tree. There were no ductal structures in the hepatic hilum. Palliative surgery appears ineffective and LT is preferred.

Rare infants present with conjugated hyperbilirubinaemia and findings consistent with biliary atresia; however, imaging or direct inspection of the biliary system reveals perfectly formed ducts resembling a miniature version of normal architecture. These infants have extrahepatic biliary hypoplasia. 2358 Kasai portoenterostomy should not be performed. Typically, jaundice clears, but biliary cirrhosis develops and LT may be required.
Nomura et al. 2359 reported a patient with this rare anomaly. Cholangiography before laparoscopic cholecystectomy demonstrated insertion of the right hepatic duct into the cystic duct.
body_text.section: Anomalous insertion of right hepatic duct

body_text.text: Anomalous ducts are found in about 15% of individuals when the bile ducts are dissected. 2360 Anomalous hepatic ducts that pass beyond the porta hepatis almost invariably arise from the right lobe and frequently from a dorsal segment. The mode of termination is variable; final entry may be into the gallbladder, cystic duct, right or common hepatic duct, junction of the cystic and common hepatic ducts or attributed to a metaplastic process. 2346 Pancreatic acini were found intermingled with peribiliary glandular acini in 4% of autopsy livers, probably representing an intrinsic component of these glands. 2347 Peribiliary glands were shown to be stem cell niches with the ability to differentiate into hepatobiliary and pancreatic cells. Similarities between peribiliary and pancreatic tissue have been proposed to explain shared pathological processes. 2348 Splenic heterotopia presenting as a mass lesion was reported by Lacerda et al. 2349 With one exception, 2350 the rare cases recently reported are examples of splenosis or subcapsular splenic implants following trauma or surgical splenectomy 2351 (see Chapter 15) . Thyroid heterotopia has been occasionally encountered (Fig. 3.174 ) and has been reported in a fetus with trisomy 18 syndrome. 2352

Congenital abnormalities of the biliary tract are best demonstrated and studied by radiographic methods. In a series of 3845 operative cholangiograms, Puente and Bannura 2353 demonstrated 'anatomical variations' (defined as those having no pathological significance) in 24% and 'congenital abnormalities' (defined as pathologically significant deviations from the normal pattern) in 18.4%. The latter included left-sided cystic duct (9.5%), aberrant hepatic ducts (4.6%) and accessory hepatic ducts (1.7%). The common channel is described in the earlier section on ductal plate malformation.

In the very rare absence of the common bile duct, the common hepatic duct empties directly into the gallbladder while the latter drains by a long cystic duct into the second part of the duodenum. 2354 even the common bile duct. 2361 Cullingford et al. 2362 reported a rare case of an anomalous right posterior segmental hepatic duct associated with a stricture and hepatolithiases. Abnormal sectional distribution of the right hepatic duct was found in 36% of 139 patients evaluated as potential donors for living-donor liver transplantation, and a classification was proposed to recognize risk areas when performing right-graft live-donor LT and tumour resections involving the right lobe. 2363 Cholecystohepatic ducts are rare and occur when there is persistence of the fetal connections between the gallbladder and liver parenchyma, with failure of recanalization of the right and left hepatic ducts. 2364 Two cases were reported in association with oesophageal atresia. 2365 Failure to recognize the presence of cholecystohepatic ducts at cholecystectomy may lead to a persistent biliary fistula, bile peritonitis, stricture or death. 2366 Cholangiography is mandatory whenever there is any doubt about the anatomy of the biliary tree, to avoid the increased morbidity and mortality of reoperation. 2366 Anomalous bile ducts may occur in association with biliary cystadenoma of the liver. 2367 Two examples of a long accessory hepatic duct have been found among 23 cases of congenital dilation of the common bile duct. 2368 Atresia of the common hepatic duct with an accessory duct has been reported. 2355 Accessory hepatic ducts may occasionally contain calculi. 2369

One duct may empty into the pylorus, or both ducts may drain into the duodenum. A choledochal cyst was associated with one case of duplicate bile ducts. 2370 Patients are usually free of symptoms until obstruction by stone or infection occurs. A case of congenital duplication involved the cystic duct and the common hepatic duct, both of which were lined by gastric mucosa. 2371

Several cases of bronchobiliary and tracheobiliary fistula have been reported. 2372 One patient had a bronchobiliary fistula, as well as a tracheo-oesophageal fistula and oesophageal atresia. 2373 Bronchobiliary fistula has been reported with biliary atresia. 2374, 2375 The bronchobiliary fistula typically arises from the proximal part of the right main stem bronchus, a short distance below the carina, and generally joins the biliary system at the level of the left hepatic duct. The proximal part of the fistula resembles a bronchus, whereas the distal part is lined by columnar and/or squamous epithelium. Patients present in early infancy with aspiration pneumonia and atelectasis. In a recent case, clinical presentation was in adolescence. 2376 Ciliated hepatic foregut cyst More than 100 cases of ciliated hepatic foregut cyst have been reported in the literature. 2377 The cyst is generally found incidentally at laparotomy or by imaging studies. It occurs more frequently in men and is most often in the medial segment of the left hepatic lobe. In one case the cyst appeared closely associated with the left hepatic vein. 2378 In most instances the cyst is unilocular (Fig. 3.175) . The mean cyst diameter is approximately 3 cm. One large cyst was associated with an elevated serum CA19-9 level. 2379 There have been a few isolated reports of squamous cell carcinoma arising in a ciliated foregut cyst (see Chapter 13) . 2380, 2381 Histologically, the cyst wall consists of four layers: pseudostratified ciliated columnar epithelium with mucous cells, subepithelial connective tissue, bundles of smooth muscle and an outermost fibrous capsule [2382] [2383] [2384] [2385] (Fig. 3.176 ). Endocrine cells are present in the cyst B A epithelium. 2385 Gastric metaplasia has also been described. 2377 In all seven cases of Chatelain et al., 2385 immunoreactivity of some cells for CD10 suggested the presence of Clara cells. The cysts are believed to arise from the embryonic foregut and to differentiate toward bronchial structures in the liver.

In the first few months of life, spontaneous bile peritonitis may occur from leakage of bile at the junction of the cystic and common bile ducts. In patients without other bile duct structural lesions, the aetiology is unknown, although congenital weakness of the bile duct walls, mucous plugs and gallstones have been suggested. 142, 143, 2386 The clinical presentation consists of conjugated hyperbilirubinaemia, ascites, failure to thrive and signs of peritoneal irritation. Sepsis can complicate the clinical picture. 2387 The diagnosis can be suspected by finding bile on abdominal paracentesis and confirmed by hepatobiliary scanning with a technetium-99m-labelled iminodiacetic acid derivative. 2386 Treatment is surgical and the prognosis excellent. Pathological descriptions of the liver are usually consistent with obstruction: ductular reaction and oedematous portal tracts.

BIBREF2409.title: The ciliated hepatic foregut cyst, an unusual bronchiolar foregut malformation: a histological, histochemical, and immunohistochemical study of 7 cases
