BIBREF2411.title: Complex spontaneous bile duct perforation: an alternative approach to standard porta hepatis drainage therapy

FIGREF0.text: Abs, Antibodies; CNS, central nervous system; CSF, cerebrospinal fluid; DPM, ductal plate malformation; EM, electron microscopy; ERCP, endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography; FAA, fumarylacetoacetase; GC, multinucleated giant cells; GGT, γ-glutamyltransferase; IHC, immunohistochemistry; mtDNA, mitochondrial DNA; nDNA, nuclear DNA; NSH, nonspecific hepatitis; PAS, periodic acid-Schiff stain; PFIC, progressive familial intrahepatic cholestasis; RT PCR, reverse-transcriptase polymerase chain reaction; T3, triiodothyronine; T4, thyroxine;TIBC, total iron-binding capacity; TSH, thyroid-stimulating hormone; VDRL, Venereal Disease Research Laboratories. a Selicorni A, Colombo C, Bonato S, et al. Biliary atresia and Kabuki syndrome: another case with long-term follow-up (letter). Am J Med Genet 2001;100:251. b Van Haelst MM, Brooks AS, Hoogeboom J, et al. Unexpected life-threatening complications in Kabuki syndrome. Am J Med Genet 2000;94:170-3. c Nydegger A, Van Dyck M, Fisher RA, et al. Hardikar syndrome: long term outcome of a rare genetic disorder. Am J Med Genet 2008;146A:2468-72.

FIGREF1.text: Neonatal hepatitis, idiopathic, with giant cell transformation (haematoxylin and eosin [H&E] stain).

FIGREF2.text: The same case as illustrated in Fig. 3.1. Detail of multinucleated giant hepatocyte. Periphery of cell (left) suggests fusion with several smaller cells. (H&E stain.)

FIGREF3.text: The same case as illustrated in Figs 3.1 and 3.2. Neutrophilic satellitosis of degenerated giant cell. (H&E stain.)

FIGREF4.text: Severe neonatal hepatitis of undetermined cause. Extensive bridging parenchymal loss with concomitant reticulin collapse divides the parenchyma into minute nodules with prominent giant cell transformation. A, H&E stain; B, Gordon-Sweet reticulin.

FIGREF5.text: Biliary atresia. Transverse sections of biliary remnants removed at portoenterostomy. A, Atretic common hepatic duct showing luminal occlusion by vascular fibrous tissue with very few inflammatory cells. B, Distorted bile duct inconsistently lined by desquamated columnar epithelium and surrounded by fibroplasia with a light inflammatory cell infiltrate. C, Cleft-like lumen devoid of epithelial lining side by side with duct structures which may represent adjacent segments of the same ducts or hyperplastic peribiliary glands. D, Hilar region close to the surgical resection line showing numerous ducts or glandular structures set in a loose, mildly inflamed fibrous tissue. (H&E stain.)

FIGREF6.text: Liver removed at transplantation 6 months after a failed Kasai procedure. Cirrhosis is characterized by small and dark-green parenchymal nodules.

FIGREF7.text: Bisected liver from patient with biliary atresia. Multiple dilated bile ducts are filled with black bilirubin casts. Some of the ducts have thick fibrous walls. The hepatic parenchyma is cirrhotic with a periseptal distribution of the cholestasis (right of the field).

FIGREF8.text: Liver removed at transplantation 8 years after 'successful'

FIGREF9.text: Biliary atresia. Liver biopsy performed at 3 weeks of age. Characteristic portal tract expansion by loose fibrous tissue containing irregularly anastomosing bile ductules at the periphery, some being dilated with inspissated bile in their lumen. (H&E stain.)

FIGREF10.text: 10 Biliary atresia. Cholangiolar reaction forming crescent-shaped profile reminiscent of the embryonal ductal plate. In our experience, this pattern may be observed irrespective of the patient having associated extrahepatic malformation. (H&E stain.)

FIGREF11.text: 11 Biliary atresia. Portal features of distal obstructive cholangiopathy are associated with giant cell transformation in the parenchyma. (H&E stain.).

FIGREF12.text: 12 Biliary atresia, cirrhotic transformation. Portoportal bridging septa made of oedematous fibrous tissue show a marginal ductular reaction and delineate small, irregularly shaped parenchymal nodules. (H&E stain.)

FIGREF13.text: 13 Biliary atresia. The same case as illustrated in Fig. 3.12. Mallory-Denk bodies in ballooned periseptal hepatocytes. (H&E stain.)

FIGREF14.text: 14 Biliary atresia. Same case as illustrated in Figs 3.12 and 3.13. Marked copper accumulation in liver cells (red granules). (Rhodanine stain.)

FIGREF15.text: 15 Biliary atresia. Inflamed and arteriole-rich, lemon-shaped fibrous tissue marks the site of a small, largely destroyed, intrahepatic bile duct. (H&E stain.)

FIGREF16.text: 16 Biliary atresia. A portal area is bereft of bile ducts. There is periportal cholangiolar reaction with an associated neutrophilic response. (H&E stain.)

FIGREF17.text: 17 Biliary atresia. Liver resection 1 year after portoenterostomy. Pattern of fibrosis and reactive small bile ducts and ductules are reminiscent of congenital hepatic fibrosis. There were only minimal chronic cholestatic features in this liver. (Periodic acid-Schiff [PAS] stain after diastase digestion.)

FIGREF18.text: 18 Biliary atresia. Same liver as illustrated in Fig. 3.17. Note absence of an interlobular bile duct and a pattern of ductular reaction reminiscent of a ductal plate malformation. (Masson trichrome stain.)

FIGREF19.text: 19 Arteriohepatic dysplasia (Alagille syndrome). Two fused portal areas lack bile ducts. (H&E stain.)

FIGREF20.text: 20 The same case as illustrated inFig. 3.19. Portal area contains vessels but no ducts. There is patchy periportal fibrosis but no cholangiolar proliferation. (Masson trichrome stain.)

FIGREF21.text: Congenital dilations of the bile ducts are classified into five types, both extrahepatic and intrahepatic:296 • Type I: a dilation of the common bile duct which may present three anatomical variations: (a) large saccular; (b) small localized; (c) diffuse fusiform

FIGREF22.text: 21 Arteriohepatic dysplasia. Micronodular cirrhosis. Note ductopenia, moderate septal inflammation and cholate stasis. (H&E stain.)

FIGREF23.text: 22 Choledochal cyst measuring about 10 cm in diameter. Note numerous vessels over the surface.

FIGREF24.text: 23 Same cyst as illustrated in Fig. 3.22. Opened, collapsed cyst has a smooth inner lining. It did not contain bile.

FIGREF25.text: 24 Segment of wall of choledochal cyst shows inflammation and focal epithelial ulceration (H&E stain). narrow portion of a choledochal cyst and suggested that the cyst could be the result of postganglionic neural dysfunction.

FIGREF26.text: 25 Autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease. Unusually prominent ductal plate in the liver of a stillborn fetus with huge polycystic kidneys. (H&E stain.) 26 Autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease. A, The bile ducts form an interrupted ring at the periphery of what should eventually become a portal area. There is no interlobular bile duct. Note branch of portal vein, as well as smaller vessels. B, The same case, with higher magnification of part of the ductal plate showing irregularity in outline of the ducts with polypoid projections into a dilated lumen. The lining epithelium is low cuboidal. (A and B, H&E stain.)

FIGREF27.text: 27 Congenital hepatic fibrosis. Jigsaw pattern of hepatic parenchyma and fibrous tissue. (PAS stain.)

FIGREF28.text: 28 Congenital hepatic fibrosis. Fibrous tissue contains small bile ducts, a few of which are dilated and contain bile. Note absence of inflammation. The adjacent hepatic parenchyma shows no evidence of cholestasis, and the patient is jaundice free. (H&E stain.)

FIGREF29.text: 29 Congenital hepatic fibrosis. The same case as illustrated in Fig. 3.28. Appearance of ducts suggests part of a ductal plate malformation. (H&E stain.)

FIGREF30.text: 30 Congenital hepatic fibrosis, 'cholangitic type'. The ducts are involved by an acute cholangitis. (H&E stain.)

FIGREF31.text: 31 Caroli disease. Section of liver shows cystically dilated bile ducts. The cystic cavities are traversed by fibrous cords, known to contain the portal vessels. The lining of the ducts is bile stained.

FIGREF32.text: 32 Caroli disease. Dilated bile ducts have thickened walls due to marked chronic inflammation. Note lymphoid follicles in the wall of one duct (left). (H&E stain.)

FIGREF33.text: 33 Caroli disease. The thickened bile duct wall reveals marked chronic inflammation. The lining epithelium is hyperplastic, except for a small segment of the duct (right). There is an area of ulceration (bottom). (H&E stain.)

FIGREF34.text: 34 Caroli disease. Markedly dilated duct contains golden-yellow inspissated bile. It shows marked inflammation, as well as ulceration (bottom). (H&E stain.)

FIGREF35.text: 35 Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease. Numerous cysts of varied size are studded throughout the liver. They contained clear fluid.

FIGREF36.text: 36 Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease. Section of liver shows multiple cysts of varied size that are lined by a flattened epithelium adjacent to a von Meyenburg complex. (H&E stain.) Figure 3.37 Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease. Collapsed cyst has a corrugated wall, and the lumen is filled in with a loose connective tissue. (Masson trichrome stain.)

FIGREF37.text: 38 Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease. Infected cysts are filled with pus. The cyst to the right has ruptured with formation of a small cholangitic abscess. (H&E stain.)

FIGREF38.text: 39 Von Meyenburg complex. Small bile ducts are embedded in a fibrous stroma. Note irregular shape of two of the ducts, each of which contains a polypoid projection. (H&E stain.)

FIGREF39.text: 40 Von Meyenburg complex. The ducts are variably dilated and contain altered bile. (H&E stain.)

FIGREF40.text: 41 Solitary bile duct cyst. The sectioned cyst has a smooth lining.

FIGREF41.text: 42 Solitary bile duct cyst. The cyst is lined by a single layer of columnar cells. (H&E stain.)

FIGREF42.text: 43 Cystic fibrosis. Periportal bridging fibrosis and ductular reaction. Note marked steatosis. (Masson trichrome stain.)

FIGREF43.text: 44 Cystic fibrosis. Expanded and moderately inflamed portal areas contain dilated bile ductules that contain greatly dilated ductules. Ductular lumens are filled with pink, inspissated secretion. (H&E stain.)

FIGREF44.text: 45 Cystic fibrosis. Dilated ductules (cholangioles) contain pink, amorphous secretion. Note absence of lining cells. (H&E stain.)

FIGREF45.text: 46 Familial intrahepatic cholestasis type 1 (FIC1) deficiency. Prominent canalicular cholestasis with pseudoglandular formation. (H&E stain.) encodes the human bile salt export pump. 645,659-661 The severe form presents in infancy, with a severe hepatitis, obvious giant cells (Figs 3.48 and 3.49), periportal and perivenular sinusoidal fibrosis

FIGREF46.text: 47 FIC1 deficiency. Dilated canaliculus with loss of microvilli is filled with characteristically loose, coarsely granular bile. (Courtesy of Dr. Alex Knisely.)

FIGREF47.text: 48 Bile salt export pump (BSEP) deficiency. Multinucleated giant hepatocytes are variably pale or heavily loaded with bile pigment. (H&E stain.)

FIGREF48.text: 49 BSEP deficiency. The same case as illustrated in Fig. 3.48 showing early portoportal and portocentral bridging fibrosis. (Reticulin stain.)

FIGREF49.text: 50 BSEP deficiency. The same case as shown in Figs 3.48 and 3.49. Immunohistochemistry for BSEP shows totally absent marking at canalicular margins, whereas the control stains adequately (inset). (Peroxidase-antiperoxidase [PAP] technique.) B A Figure 3.51 Multidrug-resistance protein 3 (MDR3) deficiency, liver biopsy from a 4-year-old boy. A, The portal tract is expanded due to inflammation and ductular reaction and increased similar to the changes seen with a chronic cholangiopathy (H&E stain). B, Immunohistochemistry for MDR3 shows complete absence of staining at canalicular margins. The normal control illustrates adequate labelling (inset). (PAP technique.)

FIGREF50.text: 52 MDR3 deficiency. Cirrhotic liver removed at transplantation shows a green discoloration and inspissated bile within dilated intrahepatic bile ducts.

FIGREF51.text: 53 MDR3 deficiency. The same case as illustrated in Fig. 3.52. A micronodular pattern with perinodular halo is in keeping with an advanced biliary cirrhosis. (H&E stain.)

FIGREF52.text: 54 MDR3 deficiency. The same case as illustrated in Fig. 3.52. Intraductal bile sludge showing a mixed bilirubin and cholesterol composition in keeping with phospholipid deficiency.

FIGREF53.text: 56 Dubin-Johnson syndrome. Liver cells contain an abundance of a brown, coarsely granular pigment. (A, H&E stain; B, Fontana stain.) C, Immunostain for canalicular multispecific organic anion transporter (cMOAT) showing no specific staining. Only the coarsely granular pigment is still seen. Normal control shows the expected pattern of staining (inset). (PAP method.)

FIGREF54.text: 57 Porphyria cutanea tarda. Needle-shaped crystals of varied length are present in the cytoplasm of liver cells. (Ferric ferricyanide stain.)

FIGREF55.text: 58 Erythropoietic protoporphyria. Brown deposits are present in canaliculi, hepatocytes and Kupffer cells. (H&E stain.)

FIGREF56.text: 59 Protoporphyrin deposits have a red to yellow birefringence with a Maltese cross configuration (H&E stain).

FIGREF57.text: 60 Erythropoietic protoporphyria. Electron micrograph showing a mass of radiating, hair-like pigment crystals in a dilated canaliculus. (Magnification ×1800.) (Courtesy of the late Dr. G Klatskin.)

FIGREF58.text: 61 Erythropoietic protoporphyria. Rounded protoporphyrin casts in canaliculi show fracture lines. Casts are solid and have a granular structure at higher magnification. Hypertrophied Kupffer cell (upper left) probably contains phagocytosed protoporphyrin. (Scanning electron microscopy [SEM] ×1250.)

FIGREF59.text: 62 Glycogenosis type III. Liver cells are swollen and have pyknotic, centrally or eccentrically located nuclei. The cytoplasm is rarefied. (H&E stain.) Figure 3.63 Glycogenosis type III. A large quantity of glycogen in liver cells (left) has been digested by diastase (right). (PAS stain before and after diastase.)

FIGREF60.text: 64 Glycogenosis type IV. Lightly eosinophilic (ground glass-like) inclusions are present in many liver cells. (H&E stain.) Figure 3.65 Glycogenosis type IV. Cytoplasmic inclusions, intensely stained with PAS (left), have been digested by pectinase (right). (PAS before and after pectinase.)

FIGREF61.text: 66 Glycogenosis type III. Micronodular cirrhosis. Note absence of inflammation and interface hepatitis. (H&E stain.)

FIGREF62.text: 67 Glycogenosis type II. Electron micrograph reveals accumulation of monoparticulate glycogen in enlarged lysosomes. Note glycogen rosettes between the lysosomes. (×15,000.)

FIGREF63.text: 68 Glycogenosis type IV. Electron micrograph shows segment of inclusion (left) consisting of non-membrane-bound fibrillar material; some glycogen rosettes are present between the inclusion and the hepatocyte cytoplasm (right) (×21,130).

FIGREF64.text: 69 Lafora disease. More or less rounded pink inclusions in the cytoplasm of periportal hepatocytes; note artefactual 'halo' around the inclusions. (H&E stain.) Figure 3.70 Lafora bodies are positively stained with colloidal iron. Note varied shapes and location in periportal hepatocytes. (Hale colloidal iron method.)

FIGREF65.text: 71 Galactosaemia. Steatosis, cholestasis and fibrous expansion of the portal tract are associated with mild ductular reaction and conspicuous periportal haemosiderosis in this liver biopsy specimen taken from a 3-week-old baby. (A, H&E stain; B, reticulin; C, Perls method for iron.)

FIGREF66.text: 72 Hereditary fructose intolerance. Electron micrograph of liver from a patient before instituting a fructose-free diet. Note prominence of the smooth endoplasmic reticulum (ser) and formation of membranous arrays (ma). Glycogen particles are aligned between layers of the smooth membranes, and enclosed cytoplasm is rarefied and watery. A cytolysosome (arrow) is also illustrated. (×28,200.) (Courtesy of Dr. M.J.Phillips.)

FIGREF67.text: 73 Hurler disease. Liver cells are large and have a rarefied cytoplasm. (H&E stain.)of small portal veins, but the pathogenesis of these lesions is undetermined.

FIGREF68.text: 74 Hurler disease. Greenish blue, punctate mucopolysaccharide is present in the cytoplasm of hepatocytes and Kupffer cells. (Hale colloidal iron method.)

FIGREF69.text: 75 Hurler disease. Perisinusoidal fibrosis in the hepatic parenchyma. Note also the swollen, vacuolated appearance of the hepatocytes. (Masson trichrome stain.)

FIGREF70.text: ,1160 Kupffer cells contain similar material but the vacuoles are smaller and are poor in lipid content. Biliary epithelial cells are markedly vacuolated on light microscopy and contain numerous clear vacuoles on EM.1160

FIGREF71.text: 76 Homozygous α1-antitrypsin (Pi*ZZ) deficiency. Eosinophilic globules of varied size are present in the cytoplasm of periportal liver cells. (H&E stain.)

FIGREF72.text: 77 α1-Antitrypsin (α1-AT) deficiency. The globules are intensely PAS positive. (PAS stain after diastase digestion.)

FIGREF73.text: 78 Presence of α1-AT in the globules is confirmed by immunohistochemistry. Note that the periphery of the larger globules is more intensely stained than the centre. (PAP technique.)

FIGREF74.text: 79 α1-AT deficiency. Electron micrograph showing moderately electron-dense, amorphous material in the cisterns of the dilated endoplasmic reticulum of a hepatocyte. The larger deposits have a serrated edge. Note the 'halo' surrounding the deposits. (×6500.)

FIGREF75.text: 80 Neonatal hepatitis syndrome in homozygous an α1-ATdeficient infant, 3 weeks old. Canalicular cholestasis is present, with minimal lobular and portal inflammation. Note presence of haemopoietic foci and apparent absence of bile duct. (H&E stain.)

FIGREF76.text: 81 Neonatal hepatitis syndrome in a homozygous α1-AT-deficient infant, 4 weeks old. Portal tract oedema, ductular reaction and inflammation with cholestasis in the adjacent parenchyma suggest the differential diagnosis of a distal obstructive cholangiopathy. (H&E stain.)

FIGREF77.text: 82 α1-AT deficiency. Liver biopsy specimen taken from an 8-week-old infant. There is portoseptal fibrous expansion with mild ductular reaction and inflammation. Note the minimal erosion of the parenchymal limiting plate, but significant periportal/periseptal steatosis. (H&E stain.)

FIGREF78.text: 83 Abundant copper accumulation (red granules) in periseptal liver cells (rhodanine stain).

FIGREF79.text: 84 α1-AT deficiency. Cirrhotic liver removed at transplantation of a 6-year-old child. A, The liver surface is greatly deformed by large, protruding nodules separated by deep grooves. The tip of the gallbladder is seen (lower part of the field). B, Cut section of the same liver shows large areas of re-expanded parenchyma separated by broad scars, a pattern reminiscent of focal nodular hyperplasia.

FIGREF80.text: 85 α1-AT deficiency. Cirrhotic nodules are surrounded by a ring of dense collagen and separated by loose fibrous tissue. Note lack of interface hepatitis and of significant inflammation. (H&E stain.)

FIGREF81.text: 86 Many α1-AT globules are present in hepatocytes throughout the cirrhotic nodules in the case illustrated in Fig. 3.85 (PAP technique).

FIGREF82.text: 87 Fibrinogen storage disease. Hepatocytes contain eosinophilic globules of varied size. (H&E stain.)

FIGREF83.text: 88 The same case as illustrated inFig. 3.87. Some globules are vacuolated, and others have a dark core. (PAS stain after diastase digestion.)

FIGREF84.text: 89 The same case as illustrated in Figs 3.87 and 3.88. Globules are immunoreactive to fibrinogen antibodies. (PAP technique.)

FIGREF85.text: 90 Electron micrograph of the same case as illustrated in Figs 3.87-3.89. The fibrinogen inclusion in the liver cell has a fingerprint-like pattern. (×31,700.)Treatment consists of administration of plasma-derived fibrinogen concentrate, cryoprecipitate or fresh-frozen plasma.1314

FIGREF86.text: 91 Tyrosine metabolic pathway. In tyrosinaemia type 1, deficient fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase (FAH) leads to accumulation of highly reactive intermediate metabolites (**) and production of succinylacetone, which is both excreted in urine (diagnostic test) and having an inhibitory effect on porphobilinogen (PBG) synthase (acute porphyria crisis and urinary excretion of 5-aminolaevulinic acid). NTBC (nitisinone) therapy blocks the degradation pathway, preventing reactive metabolite formation.

FIGREF87.text: 92 Tyrosinaemia. Section of explanted liver showing cirrhotic nodules of varied sizes and colour.

FIGREF88.text: 93 Tyrosinaemia. The same case as illustrated in Fig. 3.92. A segment of a macroregenerative nodule shows marked steatosis. (H&E stain.) Figure 3.94 Tyrosinaemia. Cellular and canalicular cholestasis with neocholangioles. (H&E stain.)

FIGREF89.text: 95 Tyrosinaemia. The same case as illustrated in Fig. 3.92. Another macroregenerative nodule shows dysplastic changes with increased cell basophilia and nucleocytoplasmic ratio.nephropathic or intermediate forms.1402 This form of the disease is diagnosed only by slit-lamp examination of the eyes.

FIGREF90.text: 96 Urea cycle metabolic pathway. Shaded oval indicates parts of the reaction inside mitochondrion.

FIGREF91.text: 97 Cystinosis. Cystine crystals are packed in the cytoplasm of hypertrophied Kupffer cells. (H&E stain.)

FIGREF92.text: 98 The same case as illustrated inFig. 3.97. Cystine crystals display brilliant silvery birefringence. (H&E stain.)

FIGREF93.text: 99 Electron micrograph shows spaces created by cystine crystals that were dissolved during processing. Several have rectangular shapes. (×32,000.)

FIGREF94.text: 100 Three-dimensional appearance of cystine crystals; some have a hexagonal shape (SEM, ×5000).

FIGREF95.text: 101 Abetalipoproteinaemia. Intestinal microvillus reveals marked vacuolization of epithelial cells. (H&E stain.)

FIGREF96.text: 102 Abetalipoproteinaemia. Kupffer cell with phagocytosed acanthocyte (transmission electron microscopy [TEM] ×40,000). Inset, Sinusoidal acanthocyte (SEM ×5000).

FIGREF97.text: 103 Cholesterol ester storage disease. This section of liver has a yellow colour and is faintly nodular. 104 Cholesterol ester storage disease. A, Kupffer cells are greatly hypertrophied and have a foamy, light-tan cytoplasm; their nuclei are pyknotic. Hepatocytes show microvesicular steatosis. (H&E stain.) B, Foamy Kupffer cells in the perivenular zone are PAS positive (PAS after diastase digestion). C, Cholesterol crystals display brilliant silvery birefringence. There is a large amount of fat (red) in liver cells. (Oil Red O stain of frozen section.) D, CD68 immunostain of macrophages highlights negatively stained lipids and needle-shaped cholesterol crystals (PAP technique).

FIGREF98.text: 105 Cholesterol ester storage disease. Electron micrograph of liver cell containing triglyceride droplets of varied size. 'Moth-eaten' appearance of several droplets is caused by presence of cholesterol crystals within them. (×10,000.)

FIGREF99.text: 106 Wolman disease. Electron micrograph demonstrating cholesterol crystals in the cytoplasm of a liver cell. (×11,000.) (Courtesy of Dr. J.E.Dimmick, Vancouver, Canada.)

FIGREF100.text: 107 GM1 gangliosidosis type I. Electron micrograph showing the cytoplasm of a Kupffer cell replaced by single membrane-bound vacuoles. Some of the vacuoles contain amorphous material, whereas others are filled with irregularly arranged fibrillar material. (×300.) (Courtesy of Dr. M. Petrelli).

FIGREF101.text: 108 GM1 gangliosidosis type II. Clusters of pale-staining foamy Kupffer cells that have eccentric nuclei. (H&E stain.) Figure 3.109 The same case as illustrated in Fig. 3.108. Ganglioside-laden Kupffer cells are intensely PAS positive. (PAS stain after diastase digestion.)

FIGREF102.text: 110 GM1 gangliosidosis type II. Electron micrograph of a Kupffer cell containing several angulated and focally membrane-bound inclusions. The inclusions are composed of granulofibrillar material and a few osmiophilic granules. (×13,500.) (Courtesy of Dr. M. Petrelli.)

FIGREF103.text: 111 Sandhoff disease. Electron micrograph of a large cytoplasmic lysosome containing single and laminated membranous structures within a finely particulate matrix. Note the size of the lysosome in comparison to the other cytoplasmic organelles. (×13,500.)

FIGREF104.text: 112 Fabry disease. Several portal macrophages are hypertrophied and have a tan-coloured cytoplasm. (H&E stain.) Figure 3.113 Fabry disease. Kupffer cells contain a granular material that stains intensely with PAS after diastase digestion.

FIGREF105.text: 115 Fabry disease. Electron micrograph showing concentric lamination of inclusion material, with periodicity of 5-6 nm. (×170,000.)

FIGREF106.text: 114 Fabry disease. Electron micrograph showing multiple dense and often laminated inclusions in hepatocytes and in a Kupffer cell. (×8800.)

FIGREF107.text: 116 Metachromatic leucodystrophy. Foamy macrophages in the tunica propria of the gallbladder. (H&E stain.) 117 Metachromatic leucodystrophy. A, Macrophages in gallbladder are PAS positive after diastase digestion. B, Macrophages are positive (brown) with the Hirsch-Pfeiffer stain.

FIGREF108.text: 118 Metachromatic leucodystrophy. A, Cluster of macrophages is present in a portal area (PAS stain after diastase digestion). B, The macrophages have a bright-red colour with Masson trichrome stain.

FIGREF109.text: 119 Pale-staining Gaucher cells have a faintly striated cytoplasm (H&E stain).

FIGREF110.text: 120 Gaucher disease. Striations are well visualized in a PAS stain after diastase digestion.

FIGREF111.text: 121 Gaucher cells exhibit marked acid phosphatase activity (red). (Phenylphosphate Mx acid phosphatase reaction.)

FIGREF112.text: 122 Gaucher cells are strongly immunoreactive to KP-1 antibody.

FIGREF113.text: 123 Gaucher disease. Section of needle biopsy specimen reveals established cirrhosis. (Masson trichrome stain.)

FIGREF114.text: 124 Electron micrograph showing cytoplasm of a Gaucher cell that is packed with tubules cut tangentially or in cross section (×8475).

FIGREF115.text: 125 Niemann-Pick disease, type C. Characteristic sea-blue histiocyte in a bone marrow smear.

FIGREF116.text: Peroxisomal biogenesis disorders. An absence or decreased number of peroxisomes results in multiple functional defects: Zellweger syndrome, neonatal adrenoleucodystrophy, infantile Refsum disease (the Zellweger spectrum), Heimler syndrome 1733 and B A Figure 3.126 Niemann-Pick disease. A, Kupffer cells storing sphingomyelin are foamy (H&E stain). B, Pale-staining clusters of foam cells containing sphingomyelin stand out in sharp contrast to glycogencontaining (purple) liver cells (PAS stain).

FIGREF117.text: 127 Niemann-Pick disease. Parenchymal fibrosis is associated with the foam cells. (Masson trichrome stain.)

FIGREF118.text: 128 Niemann-Pick disease. Electron micrograph showing electron-opaque laminated inclusions densely packed in the cytoplasm of a Kupffer cell (×7900).

FIGREF119.text: 129 Mitochondrial cytopathy. Neonatal liver failure in patient with disorder of oxidative phosphorylation complex I. Liver biopsy shows marked microvesicular steatosis. (H&E stain.)

FIGREF120.text: 130 Mitochondrial cytopathy. The parenchyma, which is dissected by thin fibrous septa with subtle ductular reaction, shows variable steatosis and oxyphilic transformation. (H&E stain.)

FIGREF121.text: 131 The same case as illustrated inFig. 3.130. Oxyphilic and microvesiculated hepatocytes are intermingled with groups of smaller hepatocytes with basophilic cytoplasm.

FIGREF122.text: 132 Mitochondrial cytopathy. Electron micrograph showing densely packed mitochondria separated by small lipid droplets. Note the mitochondrial granular appearance and loss of cristae. (×5800.) (Courtesy of Professor P. Bioulac-Sage.)

FIGREF123.text: 133 Alpers syndrome. Low-power magnification showing a micronodular cirrhosis.

FIGREF124.text: 134 Alpers syndrome. The same case as illustrated in Fig. 3.133. A, Micronodules show marked steatosis (H&E stain). B, Marked steatosis (orange), predominantly microvesicular, of liver cells in the micronodules (frozen section, Oil Red O stain).

FIGREF125.text: 135 Wilson disease. Biopsy from a 6-year-old child. Precirrhotic stage exhibiting mild portal inflammation. (H&E stain.)

FIGREF126.text: 136 Wilson disease. The same case as illustrated in Fig. 4.78 showing patchy steatosis and occasional apoptotic bodies. (H&E stain.)

FIGREF127.text: 137 Wilson disease, chronic hepatitis. Marked portal inflammation and interface hepatitis. (H&E stain.)

FIGREF128.text: 138 Wilson disease, chronic hepatitis. Ballooning and apoptotic bodies in an area of interface hepatitis. (H&E stain.)

FIGREF129.text: 139 Wilson disease, chronic hepatitis. Marked copper accumulation (red granules) in periportal liver cells. (Rhodanine stain.)

FIGREF130.text: 140 Wilson disease. Cirrhotic nodules are separated by wide bands of fibrous tissue, with many vessels and chronic inflammation. (H&E stain.)

FIGREF131.text: 141 Wilson disease. Periseptal liver cells contain Mallory-Denk bodies. (H&E stain.) necrosis in patients who present with fulminant hepatic failure (Figs 3.142 and 3.143).

FIGREF132.text: 142 Wilson disease. Massive necrosis (cell dropout) and prominent ductular reaction. (H&E stain.)

FIGREF133.text: 143 Wilson disease. The same case as illustrated inFig. 3.142showing accumulation of copper in Kupffer cells as well as in hepatocytes. (Rhodanine stain.)

FIGREF134.text: 144 Wilson disease. Electron micrograph showing mitochondria with a denser-than-normal matrix, enlarged and occasionally vacuolated granules, vacuoles with granular contents, crystalline inclusions and separation of the outer from the inner membranes. (×16,275.) 145 Indian childhood cirrhosis. A, Hepatocyte ballooning without significant steatosis is associated with Mallory-Denk bodies, which are highlighted by immunostaining for ubiquitin (B).

FIGREF135.text: 146 Indian childhood cirrhosis. The same case as illustrated in Fig. 3.145. Micronodular cirrhosis. (H&E stain.)

FIGREF136.text: 147 Indian childhood cirrhosis. The same case as illustrated in Fig. 3.145. Marked accumulation of copper-binding protein. (Orcein stain.)

FIGREF137.text: 148 Chronic granulomatous disease. A, Markedly hypertrophied Kupffer cells contain lipofuscin (black, Fontana stain). B, Portal area macrophages contain orange-coloured lipofuscin (Oil Red O stain of frozen section).

FIGREF138.text: 149 Chronic granulomatous disease. A, Macrovesicular steatosis. Portal area is inflamed and contains several large macrophage cells. (H&E stain.) B, The same case, demonstrating a cluster of macrophage cells in a portal area at higher magnification (Masson trichrome stain). 150 X-linked hyper-IgM syndrome. A, Prominent perivenular cholestasis in the liver of a patient who had sclerosing cholangitis. B, The same case, showing spherical cryptosporidia attached to the epithelium of a large bile duct. (H&E stain.)

FIGREF139.text: 151 Haemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis. A, Portal area (left) infiltrated by lymphocytes. There is mild periportal steatosis. B, Higher magnification showing erythrophagocytosis by a Kupffer cell (arrow). (H&E stain.)

FIGREF140.text: 152 Reactive haemophagocytosis in a patient with AIDS. A, Kupffer cell has phagocytosed two erythrocytes (H&E stain). B, Kupffer cell contains three erythrocytes (Biebrich scarlet).

FIGREF141.text: 153 Langerhans cell histiocytosis. Granulomatoid aggregate of Langerhans cell. (H&E stain.)

FIGREF142.text: 154 Langerhans cell histiocytosis. Higher magnification of Langerhans cell. (H&E stain.)

FIGREF143.text: 155 Langerhans cell histiocytosis. Infiltrate contains many eosinophils. (H&E stain.)

FIGREF144.text: 156 Langerhans cell histiocytosis. Langerhans cells are strongly immunoreactive to anti-CD1a.

FIGREF145.text: 157 Langerhans cell histiocytosis. The section is from a case that had a grossly visible tumour. (H&E stain.)

FIGREF146.text: 158 Langerhans cell histiocytosis. The same case depicted in Fig. 3.156, showing heavy infiltration of portal area and bile duct necrosis (left). (H&E stain.) Figure 3.159 Langerhans cell histiocytosis. Bile duct showing degenerative changes is surrounded by Langerhans cells. (H&E stain.)

FIGREF147.text: 160 Langerhans cell histiocytosis. A, High-power magnification of degenerating bile duct surrounded by a cuff of Langerhans cells (H&E stain). B, Bile duct is heavily infiltrated by Langerhans cells that are strongly immunoreactive to anti-CD1a.

FIGREF148.text: 161 Langerhans cell histiocytosis. Two fused portal areas are bereft of bile ducts. (Masson trichrome stain.)

FIGREF149.text: 162 Langerhans cell histiocytosis. End-stage micronodular cirrhosis. (Masson trichrome stain.)

FIGREF150.text: the cells express: S-100 protein (Fig. 3.163 C); pan-macrophage antigens (EBM11, HAM56, Leu-M3); antigens functionally associated with phagocytosis (Fc receptor for IgG, complement receptor)163 Rosai-Dorfman disease. A, Sinusoids are filled with large histiocytes showing leucophagocytosis. B, The same case; histiocytes display both erythro-and leucophagocytosis (H&E stain). C, The same case; histiocytes are immunoreactive for S-100 protein.

FIGREF151.text: 164 Reye syndrome. Liver cells show microvesicular steatosis. (H&E stain.) 165 Reye syndrome. A, Microvesicular steatosis is shown in this frozen section stained with Sudan Black B. B, Succinyl dehydrogenase is absent in the liver (right), contrasting with the finely granular staining in the tubules of a control rat kidney (left), in which the liver biopsy specimen has been embedded.

FIGREF152.text: 167 Kawasaki disease. Portal inflammation (left) with an acute cholangitis (arrow). Note presence of neutrophils in sinusoids and periportal steatosis. (H&E stain.)

FIGREF153.text: 166 Reye syndrome. Electron micrograph showing swollen mitochondria with loss of matrix density and both fragmentation and reduction in the number of cristae. Note absence of dense granules in the mitochondria. (×20,000.) (From Jacqueline S. Partin, Cynthia C. Daugherty, A. James McAdams, John C. Partin, William K. Schubert. A Comparison of Liver Ultrastructure in Salicylate Intoxication and Reye's Syndrome. Hepatology,1984.)

FIGREF154.text: 168 Kawasaki disease. Marked portal inflammation, predominantly neutrophilic, and acute cholangitis (arrow). (H&E stain.)

FIGREF155.text: 169 Leprechaunism. This section of liver is green and studded with pale, white nodules of varied size.

FIGREF156.text: 170 Leprechaunism. Segment of regenerative nodule is composed of large, empty hepatocytes. A PAS-stained section (not shown) confirmed the presence of glycogen in these cells. (H&E stain.)

FIGREF157.text: 171 Hermansky-Pudlak syndrome. Kupffer cells are greatly hypertrophied and contain a light-tan pigment. (H&E stain.)

FIGREF158.text: 172 Hermansky-Pudlak syndrome. Pigment in Kupffer cells displays bright-yellow autofluorescence. (Unstained section, examined under ultraviolet light.)

FIGREF159.text: 173 Pancreatic heterotopia. Pancreatic acini and several small ducts are present, but there are no islets of Langerhans. (H&E stain.)

FIGREF160.text: 174 Thyroid heterotopia. Section of nodule in liver (A) that is composed microscopically of thyroid acini (B). (H&E stain.)

FIGREF161.text: 175 Ciliated foregut cyst. This multiloculated cyst is much less common than the unilocular type. (H&E stain.)

FIGREF162.text: 176 A, Ciliated foregut cyst. The lining of pseudostratified epithelium is supported by fibrous tissue with scattered bundles of smooth muscle (Masson trichrome stain.) B, Cyst lining consists of pseudostratified columnar epithelium. Cilia are clearly seen at high magnification. (H&E stain.)
